bug.short_desc: [Migration][Build 34.1] openQA test fails in patch_sle - binutils-devel-2.31-9.29.1.aarch64 requires binutils = 2.31-9.29.1

long_desc.thetext:
## Observation
While migrated from sles12sp3 ltss to sles15sp5 we hit this kind of conflict at the patch_sle step. ------------------------------ Processing conflicts - 0 0| 2020-09-16 19:07:56 <3> susetest(5264) [zypp] SATResolver.cc(solving):610 Solverrun finished with an ERROR 0| 2020-09-16 19:07:56 <2> susetest(5264) [zypp] SATResolver.cc(resolvePool):774 SATResolver::resolvePool() done. Ret:0 0| 2020-09-16 19:07:56 <1> susetest(5264) [zypp] Resolver.cc(problems):383 Resolver::problems() 0| 2020-09-16 19:07:56 <1> susetest(5264) [zypp] SATResolver.cc(problems):1138 Encountered problems! Here are the solutions: 0| 2020-09-16 19:07:56 <1> susetest(5264) [zypp] SATResolver.cc(problems):1138 0| 2020-09-16 19:07:56 <1> susetest(5264) [zypp] SATResolver.cc(problems):1142 Problem 1: 0| 2020-09-16 19:07:56 <1> susetest(5264) [zypp] SATResolver.cc(problems):1143 ==================================== 0| 2020-09-16 19:07:56 <1> susetest(5264) [zypp] SATResolver.cc(problems):1147 binutils-devel-2.31-9.29.1.aarch64 requires binutils = 2.31-9.29.1, but this requirement cannot be provided 0| 2020-09-16 19:07:56 <1> susetest(5264) [zypp] SATResolver.cc(problems):1148 ------------------------------------ 0| 2020-09-16 19:07:56 <1> susetest(5264) [libsolv++] PoolImpl.cc(logSat):119 solver statistics: 0 learned rules, 2 unsolvable, 0 minimization steps EOL --------------------------------------------
openQA test in scenario sle-15-SP3-Migration-from-SLE12-SPx-aarch64-offline_sles12sp3_ltss_pscc_sdk_all_full_lock@aarch64 fails in [patch_sle](https://openqa.nue.suse.com/tests/4699416/modules/patch_sle/steps/67)
## Test suite description The base test suite is used for job templates defined in YAML documents. It has no settings of its own.
## Reproducible
Fails since (at least) Build [33.1](https://openqa.nue.suse.com/tests/4687844)
## Expected result
Last good: (unknown) (or more recent)
## Further details
Always latest result in this scenario: [latest](https://openqa.nue.suse.com/tests/latest?arch=aarch64&distri=sle&flavor=Migration-from-SLE12-SPx&machine=aarch64&test=offline_sles12sp3_ltss_pscc_sdk_all_full_lock&version=15-SP3)

We hit this issue again but this time it got zypper log. so I uploaded the zypper log for more information. thanks
https://openqa.nue.suse.com/tests/4712868
Created attachment 841819 zypper log
Created attachment 841820 patch_sle-y2logs
Created attachment 841831 Test Solver part1
Created attachment 841832 test solver part2
I've uploaded the test solver log, you can merge them with cat patch_sle-solverTestCase* > patch_sle-solverTestCase.tar.bz2
Stefan, could you please check if this needs to be fixed on the 15-SP3 side?

FWIW; I added binutils-devel to the 12-sp3-ltss channel meta, but we have not yet released an update for it. (actually I am expecting a toolchain binutils update in the next weeks.)
So this is a case where SERVER 12-sp3 + SERVER-LTSS 12-sp3 + SDK 12-sp3 is used in transition, but SLES 12 Sp3 LTSS does not have the -devel pacakge yet.
(There are more reports like this, where SERVER + LTSS + SDK tries to get migrated, but actually show reports of SDK+LTSS problems in SLE12).

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2021-3648: binutils: infinite loop while demangling rust symbols

long_desc.thetext:
rh#1982320
A flaw was discovered in GNU libiberty as distributed in GNU Binutils version 2.36.50. A crafted file can cause an infinite loop leading to a stack overflow and crash.
Reference: https://gcc.gnu.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=100968
References: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1982320 http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2021-3648
not relevant for SLE at the moment, but may be needed in Factory

bug.short_desc: FTBFS: bison won't compile on SP3

long_desc.thetext:
The glibc update to 2.31 caused bison sources provided by SP3 to build on SP3:
[ 136s] lib/fseterr.c: In function 'fseterr': [ 136s] lib/fseterr.c:77:3: error: #error "Please port gnulib fseterr.c to your platform! Look at the definitions of ferror and clearerr on your system, then report this to bug-gnulib." [ 136s] #error "Please port gnulib fseterr.c to your platform! Look at the definitions of ferror and clearerr on your system, then report this to bug-gnulib." [ 136s] ^~~~~

Created attachment 849517 Adjust to the glibc removal of libio.h in 2.28+
We have also seen this build failure in openSUSE:Step:FrontRunner/bison. This patch should address the problem. I'll submit in a moment.

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2020-35493: binutils: heap-based buffer overflow in bfd_pef_parse_function_stubs function in bfd/pef.c via crafted PEF file

long_desc.thetext:
rh#1911437
Objdump of GNU Binutils before 2.34 has a heap-buffer-overflow in function bfd_pef_parse_function_stubs (file bfd/pef.c) which could allow attackers to cause a denial of service or unspecified impact.
Reference: https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=25307
References: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1911437 http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2020-35493 https://access.redhat.com/security/cve/CVE-2020-35493
Upstream commit: https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;h=f2a3559d54602cecfec6d90f792be4a70ad918ab

bug.short_desc: Semantic interposition inhibits optimization of shared libraries

long_desc.thetext:
By default, any visible symbol in shared libraries (PIC) can be overwritten during runtime by the executable or mechanisms such as LD_PRELOAD, this is called semantic interposition.
This however affects optimization of shared libraries quite badly, because any call or reference to exported functions (or symbols in general) in the same library might not actually resolve to the symbol in that library anymore. Any such references have to be resolved during runtime (GOT+PLT relocations) and interprocedural optimization is not possible anymore.
For executables (also PIE) this is not the case, they can utilize direct calls and references to global data. Through the magic of copy relocations, it can even reference global data from shared objects directly. Libraries then use the copy of the global data from the executable instead of their own.
As libraries actually make up the most code on the system, optimizing for those is actually worthwhile. Using the "-fno-semantic-interposition" compiler option, interprocedural optimization can be enabled for exported symbols and the linker option "-Bsymbolic(-functions)" allows symbol references inside the same object to be resolved directly instead of going through runtime relocation.
Some libraries enable those options themselves already like openssl. Qt also used "-Bsymbolic" for a long time, but it conflicted with the "gcc-PIE" package which built incompatible executables and so it got disabled again (boo#1175278).
However, executables have to be built with that in mind (by compiling them like PIC) to avoid features which rely on interposition, like copy relocations. The "-fno-direct-access-external-data" option achieves that FWICT.
It would be great if we could build (most parts of) the distro such that libraries can be optimized more.
Thread on the GCC ML about -fno-semantic-interposition: https://gcc.gnu.org/pipermail/gcc-patches/2021-June/572018.html GCC PR report about -fno-direct-access-external-data: https://gcc.gnu.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=98112 Extensive discussion about Qt's reduce-relocations option: https://bugreports.qt.io/browse/QTBUG-86173 Blog posts about this topic: https://maskray.me/blog/2021-05-09-fno-semantic-interposition https://maskray.me/blog/2021-05-16-elf-interposition-and-bsymbolic

(In reply to Fabian Vogt from comment #0) > Using the "-fno-semantic-interposition" compiler option, interprocedural > optimization can be enabled for exported symbols [...] The way I see it, -fno-semantic-interposition is justified by the "one definition rule" in both C and C++. Having different functions with the same (qualified) name (and signature for C++) is not allowed in a program. There is still a non-standard "back door": __attribute__((weak)). So if necessary it's still possible to define overridable functions, but other libraries can't just override anything they want. It's also kind of on-by-default in Clang (not literally, but Clang does IPO on default visibility functions) and on other platforms, so there is hopefully not a lot of software out there that relies on semantic interposition.
> [...] and the linker option "-Bsymbolic(-functions)" allows symbol > references inside the same object to be resolved directly instead of going > through runtime relocation. [...] > > However, executables have to be built with that in mind (by compiling them > like PIC) to avoid features which rely on interposition, like copy > relocations. The "-fno-direct-access-external-data" option achieves that > FWICT. In the thread where Fangrui Song aka maskray proposed to enable these flags for building Clang [1], the time difference between -Bsymbolic and -Bsymbolic-functions was minor. For Qt it might very well look different though.
Address uniqueness is probably not a big issue, but it certainly can be an issue, as the standards guarantee it. So I think we could enable -Bsymbolic-functions on a per-package basis, but probably not globally. Avoiding copy relocations for -Bsymbolic might be too high a price to pay, at least in general. I don't know how common default visibility variables are, and whether they're typically used more often by the library or the program. With modern libraries I'd expect there not be a lot of exported variables, so maybe it just doesn't matter that much.
So I'd be in favor of enabling -fno-semantic-interposition by default, but not -Bsymbolic[-functions]. We can enable that where it matters and where we think it's safe.
I played with -Bsymbolic in the LLVM build once, but I'm mostly compiling C++ where the compile jobs take so long that the initial relocation processing doesn't change much. (Since we're building LLVM with Clang, we already have IPO for default visibility functions.)
[1] https://lore.kernel.org/lkml/20210501235549.vugtjeb7dmd5xell@google.com/

(In reply to Aaron Puchert from comment #1) > (In reply to Fabian Vogt from comment #0) > > Using the "-fno-semantic-interposition" compiler option, interprocedural > > optimization can be enabled for exported symbols [...] > The way I see it, -fno-semantic-interposition is justified by the "one > definition rule" in both C and C++. Having different functions with the same > (qualified) name (and signature for C++) is not allowed in a program. There > is still a non-standard "back door": __attribute__((weak)). So if necessary > it's still possible to define overridable functions, but other libraries > can't just override anything they want. It's also kind of on-by-default in > Clang (not literally, but Clang does IPO on default visibility functions) > and on other platforms, so there is hopefully not a lot of software out > there that relies on semantic interposition.
I think for GCC the ODR trumps -fsemantic-interposition though GCC applies ODR only to C++. Honza, please correct me if I'm wrong here. So I'm not sure whether -fno-semantic-interposition on its own has any measurable effect on a C++ code base.
For C there's no ODR so things are more complicated.

As I wrote to maskray on the generic-abi list ( https://groups.google.com/g/generic-abi/c/LgSC6te51uM/m/WGzfjtFKAgAJ ) I'm quite heavily opposed to disabling interposition wholesale. I would perhaps support it when restricted to C++ symbols for functions.
Also note that protected visiblity is going to be fixed on x86-64 (to not be worse than default visibility and break with copy relocations, i.e. it will work again like before 2014/15) over the next months. At that point packages choosing so can simply use that.
-Bsymbolic should be regarded as a hack in the ELF world, because ELF has symbol visibility which is (or was, and will be again) designed to be exactly that. And of course the compiler doesn't know anything about it, so can't base it's inlining decisions on it. (Which is the whole reason why people had to invent still another flag for the compiler; well, that and because protected visibility wasn't working as designed/desired).
So, my course of action would be: wait for protected symbol visibility to be fixed again, make it so that packages can select that visibility as default for C++ functions (select it in a way the compiler knows), let packages decide. Possibly make that default in the toolchain after quite some time.

Note that for instance in above generic-abi thread maskray says that most speedup for clang itself was by avoiding the symbolic relocations, i.e. what protected visibility or variants of -Bsymbolic* give you, _not_ what -fno-semantic-interposition gives you. There are unclear claims about fantastic speedups with cpython, which look a bit doubtful or are done on unrealistic microbenchmarks, that may or may not come from the disabled interposition or from reduced relocations.

(In reply to Richard Biener from comment #2) > For C there's no ODR so things are more complicated. What about C11 6.9.5?
An external definition is an external declaration that is also a definition of a function (other than an inline definition) or an object. If an identifier declared with external linkage is used in an expression (other than as part of the operand of a sizeof or _Alignof operator whose result is an integer constant), somewhere in the entire program there shall be exactly one external definition for the identifier; otherwise, there shall be no more than one.
(In reply to Michael Matz from comment #3) > I'm quite heavily opposed to disabling interposition wholesale. In my view this is more about explicitly annotating interposable functions as weak instead of allowing interposition for any function.
ELF default visibility has always implied interposability, but I think that's mostly seen as historical artifact by now. Visibility and interposability are pretty much orthogonal. Just because a library is "exporting" functions doesn't mean it's inviting others to replace them. With a few exceptions that makes absolutely no sense, and it wouldn't hurt to mark these exceptions as "weak".
> Also note that protected visiblity is going to be fixed on x86-64 (to not be > worse than default visibility and break with copy relocations, i.e. it will > work again like before 2014/15) over the next months. What are the ideas for that? Not doing copy relocations at all, or giving protected visibility a different meaning for variables?
> At that point packages choosing so can simply use that. It's going to quite a bit of time for packages to migrate to this.
I get your point, default visibility has never been a good default, and it's probably hopeless to save it. Protected visibility is more or less defined as non-interposable export, so that and hidden visibility should satisfy nearly all uses. Default visibility could still be used for the rare case where a function should actually be interposable.
But I think that's what library writers have (in almost all cases) always wanted, but didn't use it because it didn't work and was recommended against. (GCC's man page says "protected and internal are pretty useless in real-world usage so the only other commonly used option is hidden." Drepper writes: "Only the first two [default and hidden] should ever be used.")
Still, protected visibility just doesn't interpose, it doesn't error out if there is a function with the same name. So while library writers can use it to opt out of interposition (which they probably didn't want in the first place), those who'd want to interpose just get a silent failure just as if we were making -fno-semantic-interposition the default. If library writers know about their users and whether someone might interpose their functions that could be helpful, but I don't know how often that's the case.
In any event, if library writers want to actively allow interposition, an explicit "weak" attribute would communicate that intent clearly.

(In reply to Aaron Puchert from comment #5) > (In reply to Richard Biener from comment #2) > > For C there's no ODR so things are more complicated. > What about C11 6.9.5? > > An external definition is an external declaration that is also a > definition of > a function (other than an inline definition) or an object. If an identifier > declared with external linkage is used in an expression (other than as > part of > the operand of a sizeof or _Alignof operator whose result is an integer > constant), somewhere in the entire program there shall be exactly one > external > definition for the identifier; otherwise, there shall be no more than one.
That doesn't constrain the semantics - it merely says that multiple definitions will be diagnosed by the linker and no definition as well. I think there's even a stronger guarantee somewhere that mismatched declarations (as in mismatched types) invoke undefined behavior.
Compare that to the C++ ODR which says (C++14, 3.2(6)):
"There can be more than one definition [...] - each definition of D shall consist of the same sequence of tokens; and [...]"
You possibly can read the C variant as being even stronger, but then even for C there are "multiple definitions", namely for C99 inline functions, and I don't see (OK, did not exhaustively search the standard) that the standard constrains the inline function definitions.

Normally I do like language lawyering very much, but I think in this case it's not appropriate. Symbol interposition is an ELF feature, and hence, for us, a system feature; a fairly powerful one with some disadvantages. We can't just disable that feature after 30 years. At least not if there are ways where we can mitigate the disadvantages without throwing out the baby completely.
Aaron: the power of interposition doesn't lie in being able to override known symbols, but rather to override _all_ (exported) symbols. The point being that the software authors don't have to explicitely mark symbols as overridable; if they were to be required to do that, that wouldn't then make it different from them explicitely designing hooks into their interfaces. There is for instance software that hooks many libc routines (and a changeable set of other routines) in order to, well, hook them (e.g. for tracing). Symbol interposition makes this trivial. Without it you need to resort to the contortions that equivalent Windows software needs to go through (basically patching either the import table, if it exists, or even the function code itself).
Basically: if library authors would be required to make their exports hookable, we would end up with nothing being hookable. That is because the need for hooking can't be predicted; if someone needs it, it's usually not the library author but someone outside who doesn't necessarily (want to) have means to change the library.
As I've written elsewhere (probably in the above generic-abi thread): I'll concede that such hooking usually takes place for C symbols, not for other language symbols. (Though of course there's nothing that would currently prevent that, and of course e.g. valgrind does hook the global c++ allocation routines). So, I'd be willing to try disabling interposition for C++ symbols (with exceptions).
But before even that, we need to be clear what exactly we want to change and what the improvements of that change will be. Perhaps on a bit more than just clang (speedup due to fewer symbol lookups) and some anecdote from the web about cpython.
(FWIW: I do know that libqt also goes to lengths to reduce symbolic lookups, and libreoffice (at the time still openoffice) had the same problem, which is why we now have .gnu.hash, and KDE had the problem which is why we have (had) kdeinit. I.e. I know that symbolic lookups are a problem for some software (all C++!) but I also know that it's absolutely no problem at all for other software, which is why I'm hammering so much on the protected visibility, being _exactly_ the right tool for avoiding symbolic lookups from within shared libs)
And yes, Aaron: the idea for "fixing" protected vis is to not generate copy relocs for variables (i.e. cross module accesses will be indirect, like now but in the other direction). For function addresses something similar can be done; it must be the one from the defining module, not from the PLT slot in the exe. H.J. works on some patches that try to phase that into the world step by step to not break existing binaries.

bug.short_desc: VUL-0: CVE-2021-3549: binutils: heap-based buffer overflow in avr_elf32_load_records_from_section() via large section parameter

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2021-3549
A flaw was discovered in objdump as distributed in GNU Binutils version 2.36. A large section parameter can be passed to avr_elf32_load_records_from_section() leading to DoS and memory corruption.
Reference: https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=27294
Upstream patch: https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;h=1cfcf3004e1830f8fe9112cfcd15285508d2c2b7
References: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1960717 http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2021-3549

Vulnerable packages:
- SUSE:Carwos:1/binutils 2.35.1 - SUSE:SLE-12:Update/binutils 2.32 - SUSE:SLE-15-SP1:Update/binutils 2.35.1 - SUSE:SLE-15:Update/binutils 2.35.1 - openSUSE:Factory/binutils 2.36
Upstream patch [0][1].
[0] https://sourceware.org/git/?p=binutils-gdb.git;a=blobdiff_plain;f=bfd/elf32-avr.c;h=ed38ff8bb02b25863c50bfabef396b3b466677ac;hp=3859796ccc1d985079516e5e77ac9c40852834ed;hb=31c711a2b302cf27f2cb4d5dd2c495407b384b94;hpb=1cfcf3004e1830f8fe9112cfcd15285508d2c2b7 [1] https://sourceware.org/git/?p=binutils-gdb.git;a=blobdiff_plain;f=binutils/od-elf32_avr.c;h=4377a7c652a0704470acb9e4485dd9bf2e1e78b0;hp=11800e7629031d672d2ae6a33b049b1f4356b48f;hb=1cfcf3004e1830f8fe9112cfcd15285508d2c2b7;hpb=6db658c517bdfbf8e5b8c5a34caf3ff1eea332f1
Hi, we have a customer (Reactive LTSS) waiting for this fix. Can we get this moving, at least for SLE12-SP2, please?

bug.short_desc: SLES 15 - Transactional execution builtin (__builtin_tbegin_retry) requires -march=zEC12 (binutils)

long_desc.thetext:
== Comment: #0 - Andreas Krebbel <Andreas.Krebbel@de.ibm.com> - 2018-07-19 04:18:19 == The transactional execution builtin __builtin_tbegin_retry uses the ppa instruction which was not flagged as htm (hardware transactional memory) in Binutils. Hence the GNU assembler complained about this instruction not being available with just -mhtm option but without -march=zEC12.
The SLES 15 GCC by default builds with -march=z196. Just adding -mhtm should be enough to enable the builtins. The intention is to make the builtins available in code which does its own runtime checking for the availability of transactional execution instructions.
The problem can easily circumvented by passing -Wa,-march=zEC12 to GCC. This makes gas to accept all zEC12 instructions without making GCC emitting zEC12 instructions itself.
The problem has been fixed in upstream Binutils. The patch should be picked up for the next Binutils update in Sles 15.
https://sourceware.org/ml/binutils/2018-07/msg00312.html
*** Bug 1101824 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Andreas: can you please push that patch also to the binutils-2_31-branch branch? Probably that's the next binutils we're going to update to with the toolchain update later this year, and so we'd pick it up automatically.

------- Comment From Andreas.Krebbel@de.ibm.com 2018-07-24 07:07 EDT------- (In reply to comment #5) > Andreas: can you please push that patch also to the binutils-2_31-branch > branch? > Probably that's the next binutils we're going to update to with the toolchain > update later this year, and so we'd pick it up automatically.
Ok. Done.
------- Comment From Andreas.Krebbel@de.ibm.com 2019-09-19 04:30 EDT------- The requested patch is part of binutils-2.31-branch.diff in binutils-2.31-6.3.1.src.rpm

bug.short_desc: [Tracker] binutils: support s390x arch13 instructions

long_desc.thetext:
For fate#327074 and jsc#SLE-6206 we need either a backport of patches adding support for new z13 instructions, or an update of binutils version to at least 2.32. These new instructions are used by an updated glibc, which is also requested as feature for sle12-sp5 (fate#327072), so the binutils update is a prerequisite for this.
This bug is for the purpose of tracking that. The patches are from these commits: f47998d69f8d290564c022b010e63d5886a1fd7d S/390: Support vector alignment hints 13daa8e4889a971309f7d46a8d49129cb26088a5 S/390: Fix optional operand handling after memory addresses 126b2985ce48d879c9d829b2245e4f00d05a6a74 S/390: Implement instruction set extensions ba354106f02e25c9adc3dc1364d6a974216ec94e S/390: arch13: Add instruction descriptions 40f382e88d0391ffaa4098c92cbf339a7924a629 S/390: arch13: Adjust to recent changes This patch is a non-functional change but still desirable for sake of completeness:
As the update of the toolchain module is some time away but we want to get some free testing from the sp5 build, we go the patch route for now.
We also don't want source split between current SLE12 binutils and the SLE12-SP5 binutils (later in the summer all will be upgraded to 2.32 or 2.33 anyway). For the time being we submit binutils to SLE-12:Update and to SLE-12-SP5:GA, if the former is checked in first the latter isn't necessary anymore, if the other way around, then the sp5 variant can be removed once sle12-update is checked in.

bug.short_desc: SLES 15 SP3 Snapshot7 - [P10/Denali] ltrace test suite compilation issues

long_desc.thetext:
--Problem Description--
[P10/Denali][SLES15SP3 Snapshot7] ltrace test suite compilation issues
---Environment-- Kernel Build: Sles15SP3 Snapshot7 System Name : ltcden13-lp5 Model/Type : P10 Platform : vm
---Uname output--- localhost:~ # uname -a Linux localhost 5.3.18-43-default #1 SMP Wed Jan 13 10:25:28 UTC 2021 (404436f) ppc64le ppc64le ppc64le GNU/Linux localhost:~ #
--system Environment-- localhost:~ # cat /proc/cmdline BOOT_IMAGE=/boot/vmlinux-5.3.18-43-default root=UUID=8112ad7e-a838-4419-9950-e6d5d1e0d236 splash=verbose mitigations=auto fadump= crashkernel=2048M localhost:~ # tail /proc/cpuinfo processor : 47 cpu : POWER10 (architected), altivec supported clock : 2400.000000MHz revision : 1.0 (pvr 0080 0100)
timebase : 512000000 platform : pSeries model : IBM,9080-HEX machine : CHRP IBM,9080-HEX MMU : Radix localhost:~ # lscpu Architecture: ppc64le Byte Order: Little Endian CPU(s): 48 On-line CPU(s) list: 0-47 Thread(s) per core: 8 Core(s) per socket: 6 Socket(s): 1 NUMA node(s): 1 Model: 1.0 (pvr 0080 0100) Model name: POWER10 (architected), altivec supported Hypervisor vendor: pHyp Virtualization type: para L1d cache: 32K L1i cache: 48K L2 cache: 1024K L3 cache: 4096K NUMA node1 CPU(s): 0-47 Physical sockets: 1 Physical chips: 1 Physical cores/chip: 7 localhost:~ # lparstat
System Configuration type=Dedicated mode=Capped smt=8 lcpu=6 mem=31069760 kB cpus=0 ent=6.00
%user %sys %wait %idle physc %entc lbusy app vcsw phint ----- ----- ----- ----- ----- ----- ----- ----- ----- ----- 0.81 0.70 0.04 98.45 0.00 0.00 1.51 0.00 182235 1 localhost:~ # free -h total used free shared buff/cache available Mem: 29Gi 898Mi 28Gi 21Mi 473Mi 28Gi Swap: 31Gi 0B 31Gi localhost:~ #
--Steps to reproduce--
1. Install ltrace source on sles 15 sp3 zypper source-install ltrace localhost:/usr/src/packages/SOURCES # ls -l total 640 -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 461 Feb 7 2018 arm-trace.patch -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 56 Jul 23 2008 baselibs.conf -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 267585 Sep 4 2014 ltrace-0.7.91-g6c6bcc3.tar.bz2 -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 513 Nov 27 2017 ltrace-fix-build.patch -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 298 Feb 7 2018 ppc-ptrace.patch -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 1075 Jul 13 2016 readdir.patch
2. Extract ltrace tarball and configure tar -xjf ltrace-0.7.91-g6c6bcc3.tar.bz2 cd ltrace-0.7.91/ ./autogen.sh CFLAGS=-Wno-error ./configure make
3. Run test suites cd testsuite/ make check
--log-- Running ./ltrace.torture/arm-singlestep.exp ... Running ./ltrace.torture/ia64-sigill.exp ... Running ./ltrace.torture/ppc-lwarx.exp ... Running ./ltrace.torture/signals.exp ... compile failed for ltrace test, ./ltrace.torture/signals.c: In function ?main?: ./ltrace.torture/signals.c:27:7: warning: implicit declaration of function ?getpid?; did you mean ?fgetpos?? [-Wimplicit-function-declaration] pid=getpid(); ^~~~~~ fgetpos ./ltrace.torture/signals.c:40:7: warning: implicit declaration of function ?usleep?; did you mean ?fseek?? [-Wimplicit-function-declaration] usleep(100); ^~~~~~ fseek Testcase compile failed, so all tests in this file will automatically fail .Running ./ltrace.torture/vfork-thread.exp ...
=== Summary ===
# of expected passes 200 # of unexpected failures 175 # of unsupported tests 1 make[3]: *** [Makefile:492: check-DEJAGNU] Error 1 make[3]: Leaving directory '/usr/src/packages/SOURCES/ltrace-0.7.91/testsuite' make[2]: *** [Makefile:589: check-am] Error 2 make[2]: Leaving directory '/usr/src/packages/SOURCES/ltrace-0.7.91/testsuite' make[1]: *** [Makefile:399: check-recursive] Error 1 make[1]: Leaving directory '/usr/src/packages/SOURCES/ltrace-0.7.91/testsuite' make: *** [Makefile:591: check] Error 2
Below attaching the complete log
==== Since you installed this from the ltrace-0.7.91-4.3.src, does it make a difference if you do rpmbuild -bp ltrace.spec and build from /usr/src/packages/BUILD directory?
Was the process you were using before working in prior SLES 15 SP3 milestones?
Created attachment 845504 console log
Created attachment 845505 supportconfig
You did not apply the patches.

------- Comment From kalshett@in.ibm.com 2021-01-26 07:28 EDT------- (In reply to comment #4) > Since you installed this from the ltrace-0.7.91-4.3.src, does it make a > difference if you do rpmbuild -bp ltrace.spec and build from > /usr/src/packages/BUILD directory? > I have tried with rpmbuild option... attached complete log.
> Was the process you were using before working in prior SLES 15 SP3 > milestones? We may have run this, but currently we don't have logs that I can look into previously run ltrace build log.
As part of P10 execution we need to run this ltrace source test suites, hence we have done it on SLES 15 SP3.
------- Comment From kalshett@in.ibm.com 2021-01-26 07:30 EDT------- (In reply to comment #8) > You did not apply the patches.
----- snippet of build log where patches seems applied ----- ..... + cd ltrace-0.7.91 + /usr/bin/chmod -Rf a+rX,u+w,g-w,o-w . + echo 'Patch (readdir.patch):' Patch (readdir.patch): + /usr/bin/patch --no-backup-if-mismatch -p1 --fuzz=0 patching file sysdeps/linux-gnu/proc.c + echo 'Patch #2 (ltrace-fix-build.patch):' Patch #2 (ltrace-fix-build.patch): + /usr/bin/patch --no-backup-if-mismatch -p1 --fuzz=0 patching file testsuite/ltrace.main/filters.exp + echo 'Patch #3 (ppc-ptrace.patch):' Patch #3 (ppc-ptrace.patch): + /usr/bin/patch --no-backup-if-mismatch -p1 --fuzz=0 patching file sysdeps/linux-gnu/ppc/ptrace.h + echo 'Patch #4 (arm-trace.patch):' Patch #4 (arm-trace.patch): + /usr/bin/patch --no-backup-if-mismatch -p1 --fuzz=0 patching file sysdeps/linux-gnu/arm/trace.c + exit 0 Executing(%build): /bin/sh -e /var/tmp/rpm-tmp.8AshXb + umask 022 + cd /usr/src/packages/BUILD + /usr/bin/rm -rf /usr/src/packages/BUILDROOT/ltrace-0.7.91-4.3.ppc64le .....
Created attachment 845533 ltrace build logs

Indeed, this package does not build on SP3. It is inherited from SP0 so it probably builds there.
This is problem for Leap buildability so it should be fixed.
It is also problem because testsuite running as part of the build never runs on the current SP for inherited packages.
------- Comment From kalshett@in.ibm.com 2021-02-08 08:46 EDT------- Any progress/updates on this?

We aren't claiming 100% clean results of testsuites included in random packages. Some of the fails are pre-existing upstream, some of them harmless, some of them due to too different (from testsuites expectation) compilation environment. In this case in particular it's due to newer glibc in SP3 that some testcases of ltrace simply can't be compiled anymore. This is no defect in ltrace itself.
It's good to track these fails for eventual analysis, but it's nothing that would hold off any release. In comparison, if you find bugs hindering actual use (by users) of any of our supported packages, that might come out different.
So, reducing severity and priority.

------- Comment From kalshett@in.ibm.com 2021-02-10 05:28 EDT------- (In reply to comment #14) > We aren't claiming 100% clean results of testsuites included in random > packages. > Some of the fails are pre-existing upstream, some of them harmless, some of > them > due to too different (from testsuites expectation) compilation environment. > In this case in particular it's due to newer glibc in SP3 that some testcases > of ltrace simply can't be compiled anymore. This is no defect in ltrace > itself. > > It's good to track these fails for eventual analysis, but it's nothing that > would hold off any release. In comparison, if you find bugs hindering > actual use > (by users) of any of our supported packages, that might come out different. > > So, reducing severity and priority.
Agreed, will make P3.

bug.short_desc: cross-arm-binutils missing symlinks

long_desc.thetext:
cross-arm-binutils seems to provide arm-none-eabi-* utils vis symlinks to arm-suse- equivalents. see below.
in the process of building qmk for arm I noticed arm-none-eabi-size is missing.
lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root 28 Mar 26 11:26 /usr/bin/arm-none-eabi-strip -> arm-suse-linux-gnueabi-strip lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root 30 Mar 26 11:26 /usr/bin/arm-none-eabi-readelf -> arm-suse-linux-gnueabi-readelf lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root 29 Mar 26 11:26 /usr/bin/arm-none-eabi-ranlib -> arm-suse-linux-gnueabi-ranlib lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root 30 Mar 26 11:26 /usr/bin/arm-none-eabi-objdump -> arm-suse-linux-gnueabi-objdump lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root 30 Mar 26 11:26 /usr/bin/arm-none-eabi-objcopy -> arm-suse-linux-gnueabi-objcopy lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root 25 Mar 26 11:26 /usr/bin/arm-none-eabi-nm -> arm-suse-linux-gnueabi-nm lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root 29 Mar 26 11:26 /usr/bin/arm-none-eabi-ld.bfd -> arm-suse-linux-gnueabi-ld.bfd lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root 25 Mar 26 11:26 /usr/bin/arm-none-eabi-ld -> arm-suse-linux-gnueabi-ld lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root 25 Mar 26 11:26 /usr/bin/arm-none-eabi-as -> arm-suse-linux-gnueabi-as lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root 25 Mar 26 11:26 /usr/bin/arm-none-eabi-ar -> arm-suse-linux-gnueabi-ar

OK, so the reason is that 'size' is only present as /usr/bin/$T-size but _not_ as /usr/$T/bin/size and thus the
%if "%{TARGET}" == "arm" # Instead of building duplicate binutils, add symlinks for f in %buildroot/usr/$T/bin/* ; do for p in arm-none-eabi; do ln -sf %{_bindir}/$T-$(basename $f) %buildroot%{_bindir}/$p-$(basename $f) done done %endif
loop doesn't pick it up. Some clever shell foo could instead walk %buildroot/usr/bin/$T-* or the list of binaries could be spelled out and links created based on target existence ...
Of course the question is why /usr/$T/bin/size does not exist (which would be a question to ask upstream binutils).

bug.short_desc: Astonishing performance drop for strip of large binaries [ref:_00D1igLOd._5001iahslM:ref]

long_desc.thetext:
Our partner is observing that it takes around 40 times as long to strip one of their (large) binaries, which has ~100000 sections with strip from the binutils v2.35-7.11.1 maintenance update, compared to the 2.32-7.8.1 version shipping with SLE 15 SP2 FCS.
Detailed description: ===================== Working version and time taken: GNU strip (GNU Binutils; SUSE Linux Enterprise 15) 2.32.0.20190909-7.8 [...] -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 1.5G Feb 26 08:47 /MTASCT.TLM_MTASCT.elf.1.0.0.0.adp-dicos-x86_64.native real 0m6.353s user 0m5.364s sys 0m0.988s
Version with performance drop and time taken: GNU strip (GNU Binutils; SUSE Linux Enterprise 15) 2.35.0.20200915-7.11 (*) [...] -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 1.5G Feb 26 08:47 /MTASCT.TLM_MTASCT.elf.1.0.0.0.adp-dicos-x86_64.native real 4m12.192s user 4m10.777s sys 0m1.076s
The slowness appeared somewhere between 2.32 and 2.35.
Customer thinks the most interesting and relevant property of this binary is that it has almost 100000 sections which could possibly be the root cause. There seems to be a recent commits in strip and one of them even mentioned that things will go bad if the section count is large.
https://sourceware.org/git/?p=binutils-gdb.git;a=commitdiff;h=44466e45c51b1c68ed2f95f86bcdb1f18f08b380
FIXME: Currently this function can result in a serious performance penalty for files with secondary relocs and lots of sections. The proper way to fix this is for _bfd_elf_copy_special_section_fields() to chain secondary relocs together and then to have this function just walk that chain. */
Other interesting tidbit, the newer versions of objcopy are also equally slow for this giant binary. It is likely that the root cause is in some shared code between strip and objcopy.
Reproduction: ============= Yes, but unfortunately the specific binary cannot be shared. Hopefully the bit about 100000 sections could help with the reproduction. If not we could as a last resort ask the customer to try to create one.
Workaround possible: ==================== Yes, to use the 2.32 version of binutils
(*) I am currently waiting for a verification that the problem also exists on the current binutils-2.35.1-7.18.1. The bug will updated once this info is available.

Please excuse this somewhat premature bug with regards to awaiting confirmation that the problem persists on the latest version.
Customer name : Ericsson AB email domain : ericsson.com Architecture : x86_64 Case and refid : 00278678 ref:_00D1igLOd._5001iahslM:ref SG-ID : 60386
L3:60386 is now handled by Jean Delvare.

Unfortunately it does not look like the FIXME has been addressed upstream yet. So I don't think the maintenance update is going to help.
As I read it, the commit you mentioned is not causing the slowdown. It is only documenting it, and avoiding it when possible (which doesn't seem to be the case for your customer). I suspect that the actual slowdown comes from:
commit a8e14f4cc2badfcf959f5e2cc57a941dc43f72d4 Author: Nick Clifton Date: Thu Mar 5 15:47:15 2020 +0000
Add support for ELF files which contain multiple reloc sections which all target the same section.
which is also part of binutils 2.35. Michael will hopefully confirm this.
Michael, is reverting this specific change from SLES 15 SP2 an option for the time being? Or do we need to persuade upstream to implement the suggestion in the FIXME?

Please first verify that the problem still exists with binutils 2.35.1 as currently released as update for SLE-15.
Then, we need a reproducer. The mentioned commits only deal with secondary relocation sections, that is, ELF files where a section is affected by multiple relocation sections. Those are unusual and shouldn't occur trivially in the wild, which is why it's important to see the specifics of a reproducer.
As Jean already mentioned the actual slowdown (if it's really this problem!) will come from commit a8e14f4c, which implemented that support. Before it one should have gotten a warning message corresponding to this moved code:
- _bfd_error_handler - /* xgettext:c-format */ - (_("%pB: warning: multiple relocation sections for section %pA \ -found - ignoring all but the first"), - abfd, target_sect);
(a warning message should still be there!) commit 44466e4 merely improved the newly added code by not invoking it when not necessary (which should be the case for all normal ELF files that aren't specifically crafted to contain secondary relocation sections).
I've verified that the submitted binutils do contain both patches. Even the original maintenance update corresponding to version 2.35.0.20200915-7.11 should have contained both, but it can't hurt to verify that 2.35.1-7.18 still has the problem.

(In reply to Jean Delvare from comment #3) > Michael, is reverting this specific change from SLES 15 SP2 an option for > the time being?
That would reintroduce a bug with crafted binaries, and if this is really the same problem also affecting the customers binary it would also reintroduce a bug with _those_. (Seemingly a bug that was harmless before, which makes it even more important to see a reproducer to be sure that the mentioned commits are really the cause and not something completely different).
And before we invest much time in fixing the slowness problem of commit a8e14f4c we really want to be sure that we're barking up the right tree.

Customer has verified that the problem also exists on the latest binutils version :
224.76user 0.58system 3:46.15elapsed 99%CPU (0avgtext+0avgdata 356368maxresident)k 399800inputs+163120outputs (0major+109416minor)pagefaults 0swaps
I have asked them for a test binary to use and full output of the command dialog.

It appears that this test binary is difficult to get (even for my contact at the customer).
When running the strip command the output seems empty running it with the verbose option just results in the following line :
copy from 'MTASCT.TLM_MTASCT.elf.1.0.0.0.adp-dicos-x86_64.native' [elf64-x86-64] to 'MTASCT.TLM_MTASCT.elf.1.0.0.0.adp-dicos-x86_64.native.2.35.1.20201123' [elf64-x86-64]
Customer is asking if they should try some alternative options or could it be helpful for example to run with an strace or similar ?

Created attachment 848489 strace
My customer contact has given up on getting and/or producing a test binary. However he has provided an strace of an executing against the problematic binary. Hopefully this can be of use to the analysis at our end restarted.
Ping Michael

Well, I'm not sure what to do here, the strace doesn't show anything, except that there the program is doing stuff without syscalls in between, i.e. CPU work. Would the customer be willing to try a binutils version with the commit disabled (and hence susceptible to the bugs fixed with it), to see if that's really the one causing the speed problem?
Customer is willing to test a TEST package.

I built a TEST package for the customer:
https://ptf.suse.com/7a8fed5a4111fab9e4335fb24eb4e6ef/sle-module-basesystem-15-sp2/22260/x86_64/20210507-test
This package has the following 3 upstream commits reverted:
commit 790244d25897928fd5c950ee4e4ef84e3e9fd6ed (Note: This is the same as 44466e45c51b1c68ed2f95f86bcdb1f18f08b380 in a different branch.) Author: Nick Clifton <nickc@redhat.com> Date: Thu Sep 3 16:00:48 2020 +0100
Partially fix a quadratic slowdown when processing secondary relocations for inputs with lots of sections.
commit a859124df20f6544dbef96084e4e024bccebd853 Author: Alan Modra <amodra@gmail.com> Date: Wed Mar 18 07:31:47 2020 +1030
tidy elf_backend calls
commit a8e14f4cc2badfcf959f5e2cc57a941dc43f72d4 Author: Nick Clifton <nickc@redhat.com> Date: Thu Mar 5 15:47:15 2020 +0000
Add support for ELF files which contain multiple reloc sections which all target the same section.
Please have the customer give it a try and report.
Thanks, Jean. Passed on to customer.

My contact (not the originator) at the customer has tested the TEST package in a slightly different environment, but with a copy of the problematic binary at hand. Thus the times vary a little from comment 0. Still the results appear to support the analysis :
<snip> With the copy I have I did some tests and it seems to work for me. In short I think I can confirm that the change seems to work.
Fault recreated locally: bash-4.4# cp MTASCT.TLM_MTASCT.elf.1.0.0.0.adp-dicos-x86_64.native binfile bash-4.4# time strip binfile -o binfile.strip
real 7m14.846s user 7m6.400s sys 0m2.043s bash-4.4# ls -lrt binfile* -rw-r--r--. 1 root root 2452517984 May 28 15:50 binfile -rw-r--r--. 1 root root 120421960 May 28 15:58 binfile.strip
bash-4.4# rpm -qa | egrep "binutils|libctf" libctf0-2.35.1-7.18.1.x86_64 libctf-nobfd0-2.35.1-7.18.1.x86_64 binutils-2.35.1-7.18.1.x86_64
With the TEST rpms:
bash-4.4# cp MTASCT.TLM_MTASCT.elf.1.0.0.0.adp-dicos-x86_64.native binfile bash-4.4# time strip binfile -o binfile.strip
real 0m9.473s user 0m6.025s sys 0m1.946s bash-4.4# ls -lrt binfile* -rw-r--r--. 1 root root 2452517984 May 28 15:59 binfile -rw-r--r--. 1 root root 120421960 May 28 15:59 binfile.strip
bash-4.4# rpm -qa | grep TEST libctf-nobfd0-2.35.1-7.18.1.22260.1.TEST.1183909.x86_64 binutils-2.35.1-7.18.1.22260.1.TEST.1183909.x86_64 libctf0-2.35.1-7.18.1.22260.1.TEST.1183909.x86_64 </snip>
Michael, are you going to bring this up upstream and discuss it with Nick Clifton?

(In reply to Jean Delvare from comment #15) > Michael, are you going to bring this up upstream and discuss it with Nick > Clifton?
I don't see that helping without the binary, so no. But I'll try to fiddle with the patch myself to see if I can speed it up. I'll do that by doing assumptions on what the real problem will be, and in order to help with that reducing the possibilities would help.
So, if that large binary absolutely cannot be provided to me (which would be the best thing, and given we are under default NDAs should not actually be a problem) then at least the output of 'readelf -aW' on that binary would help. It should be sufficiently unspecific to not reveal any relevant secrets.

Customer has managed to provide a reproducer :
<snip> $ cat many_sections.sh
seq 100000 | xargs -I COUNTER echo 'int dataCOUNTER = COUNTER; __attribute__((section(".mytext_COUNTER"))) int myfuncCOUNTER() { return dataCOUNTER; }' > many_sections.cc
$ ./many_sections.sh $ g++ -g -c many_sections.cc -o many_sections.o $ time strip -g many_sections.o -o many_sections.o_stripped1 </snip>
I have verified it in a VM in my lab (2G of RAM, 8 vCPUs) :
$ rpm -q binutils binutils-2.32-7.8.1.x86_64
$ time many_sections.sh
real 0m55.144s user 0m43.896s sys 0m13.602s
$ sudo zypper up binutils $ rpm -q binutils binutils-2.35.1-7.18.1.x86_64
$ time strip -g many_sections.o -o many_sections.o_stripped1
real 6m8.963s user 6m8.774s sys 0m0.168s

(In reply to Andreas Taschner from comment #17) Duh, Andreas ...
> $ time many_sections.sh ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ Wrong output copied, sorry. That was of course supposed to be : $ time strip -g many_sections.o -o many_sections.o_stripped1
real 0m0.728s user 0m0.588s sys 0m0.124s
> $ sudo zypper up binutils > $ rpm -q binutils > binutils-2.35.1-7.18.1.x86_64 > > $ time strip -g many_sections.o -o many_sections.o_stripped1 > > real 6m8.963s > user 6m8.774s > sys 0m0.168s
Hah, most excellent! To show that a local testcase really helps, I have a patch :-) https://sourceware.org/pipermail/binutils/2021-June/116869.html

(In reply to Michael Matz from comment #19) > Hah, most excellent! To show that a local testcase really helps, I have > a patch :-) > https://sourceware.org/pipermail/binutils/2021-June/116869.html
Wonderful, thanks. Seeing that the patch is already accepted upstream, could we get the customer a PTF, Jean ?

Created attachment 850088 [PATCH] bfd/elf: Don't read non-existing secondary relocs
For the record, this is the patch I used to build the PTF.

PTF is available for download:
https://ptf.suse.com/7a8fed5a4111fab9e4335fb24eb4e6ef/sle-module-basesystem-15-sp2/22260/x86_64/20210609/
Please have the customer give it a try and report.
Customer has verified the PTF. Thank you all for getting this nailed.

Thanks. Ending L3 and passing over to maintenance.
Summary of the bug:
This is a performance regression introduced upstream in binutils version 2.35 (commit a8e14f4cc2ba - "Add support for ELF files which contain multiple reloc sections which all target the same section."). After this commit, the algorithm used by "strip" becomes quadratic, so a large binary with many sections would take a very long time to process.
The code can be optimized in such a way that only rare cases will trigger the quadratic behavior. In the common case, the algorithm becomes essentially linear again, solving the performance regression.

attachment.desc: [PATCH] bfd/elf: Don't read non-existing secondary relocs

long_desc.thetext: The devel:gcc gdb package runs the testsuite for sle-15 s390 -m31, and we run into: ... gnatlink foo.ali -m31 -g -O2 -o /home/abuild/rpmbuild/BUILD/gdb-10.0.50.20200806/build-s390x-suse-linux/gdb/testsuite.unix.-m31/outputs/gdb.ada/O2_float_param/foo^M /usr/lib64/gcc/s390x-suse-linux/7/../../../../s390x-suse-linux/bin/ld: BFD (GNU Binutils; SUSE Linux Enterprise 15) 2.32.0.20190909-6.8 internal error, aborting at ../../bfd/bfd.c:1078 in _bfd_doprnt_scan^M ^M /usr/lib64/gcc/s390x-suse-linux/7/../../../../s390x-suse-linux/bin/ld: Please report this bug.^M ^M collect2: error: ld returned 1 exit status^M gnatlink: error when calling /usr/bin/gcc^M gnatmake: *** link failed.^M compiler exited with status 1 ...
Hmm, I'm not sure I want to investigate this one as the binutils update to 2.35 will come soon. I'll try reproducing first.

Okay, still happens with 2.35 as well, from ibs://home:matz2:sle15sp2/gdb:testsuite, gdb-s390x-suse-linux-m31.log :
gnatlink foo.ali -m31 -g -O2 -o /home/abuild/rpmbuild/BUILD/gdb-9.2/build-s390x- suse-linux/gdb/testsuite.unix.-m31/outputs/gdb.ada/O2_float_param/foo /usr/lib64/gcc/s390x-suse-linux/7/../../../../s390x-suse-linux/bin/ld: BFD (GNU Binutils; home:matz2:sle15sp2) 2.35 internal error, aborting at ../../bfd/bfd.c: 1307 in _bfd_doprnt_scan
/usr/lib64/gcc/s390x-suse-linux/7/../../../../s390x-suse-linux/bin/ld: Please re port this bug.
So, confirmed, but not urgent, as SLE15 doesn't need s390 (m31) extensively. For after my vacation.

bug.short_desc: gdb --with(out)-debuginfod

long_desc.thetext:
Hello,
we've noticed that on a SLES 15 SP3, gdb is delivered without debuginfod support. From a support perspective, debuginfod is a great feature and we will provide this service in our dev and support setup. But therefore we need a gdb with debuginfod support on SLES installations.
Would you please check and enable debuginfod support for the gdb build on SLES 15 SP3.
Kind regards Michael
# cat /etc/os-release NAME="SLES" VERSION="15-SP3 RC1"
# rpm -qa gdb gdb-10.1-8.24.1.x86_64
# gdb --version GNU gdb (GDB; SUSE Linux Enterprise 15) 10.1
# gdb --config This GDB was configured as follows: configure --host=x86_64-suse-linux --target=x86_64-suse-linux ... --without-debuginfod
The issue is that enabling isn't enough, we'd also need to ship debuginfod itself which requires updating elfutils.

We don't need a debuginfod on SLES15 SP3, from our perspective a gdb with debuginfod support is sufficient, because the debuginfod setup itself is already available.
Well, I don't know how libdebuginfod would be linked to gdb in your rpm, but with static linking this should not be an issue.

GDB uses /usr/lib64/libdebuginfod.so.1, provided by package libdebuginfod1, which is build from source package elfutils-debuginfod. Those packages are currently not available in SLE-15.
The elfutils-debuginfod package build creates a libdebuginfod.a but doesn't package it. But in principle it should be possible to build gdb against a static libdebuginfod.a, although that might require some (hopefully trivial) configury changes in gdb, I'm not sure. Integrating an elfutils build as part of the gdb package build however may be more complicated.
Anyway, AFAICT, the simplest way to support this would be to (partially?) copy the elfutils-debuginfod package to SLE-15.
Is this a feature request, and should it be managed somewhere as such?

Yes, this is a feature request as far as SLE-15 is concerned, so needs to go through that process. Stefan W (probably?): please push it through jira, IIRC there was already one related to debuginfod and sle-15.
(And yes, the easiest practical way is of course to update elfutils)

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2017-8397: binutils: libbfd: heap buffer overflow in objdump

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 723333 21434_upstream_crash_info
Ref: https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2017-8397 =================================================== Description
The Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.28, is vulnerable to an invalid read of size 1 and an invalid write of size 1 during processing of a corrupt binary containing reloc(s) with negative addresses. This vulnerability causes programs that conduct an analysis of binary programs using the libbfd library, such as objdump, to crash. ===================================================
Hyperlink
[1] https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=21434
[2] https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;h=04b31182bf3f8a1a76e995bdfaaaab4c009b9cb2 (see https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=21434#c1)
(open-)SUSE: https://software.opensuse.org/package/binutils
2.28 (TW, official repo) 2.26.1 (42.{1,2}, official repo)

QA REPRODUCER:
valgrind objdump -W bug_8
should not report:
==25984== Invalid read of size 1 ==25984== at 0x554DDA9: bfd_perform_relocation (in /usr/lib64/libbfd-2.26.1.so) ==25984== by 0x554EAE6: bfd_generic_get_relocated_section_contents (in /usr/lib64/libbfd-2.26.1.so) ==25984== by 0x554FBA2: bfd_simple_get_relocated_section_contents (in /usr/lib64/libbfd-2.26.1.so)
Code looks buggy in SLE10 already.

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2017-8395: binutils: libbfd: objcopy segfault - null pointer dereferencing (_bfd_generic_get_section_contents function)

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 723327 21431_upstream_crash_info
Ref: https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2017-8395 ==================================================== Description
The Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.28, is vulnerable to an invalid write of size 8 because of missing a malloc() return-value check to see if memory had actually been allocated in the _bfd_generic_get_section_contents function. This vulnerability causes programs that conduct an analysis of binary programs using the libbfd library, such as objcopy, to crash. ====================================================
Hyperlink
[1] https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=21431
[2] https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;h=e63d123268f23a4cbc45ee55fb6dbc7d84729da3 (see https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=21431#c2)
(open-)SUSE: https://software.opensuse.org/package/binutils
2.28 (TW, official repo) 2.26.1 (42.{1,2}, official repo)
Created attachment 723328 21431_upstream_crash_info_additional

QA REPRODUCER:
$ objcopy --compress-debug-section bug_2 Segmentation fault
should not cause a segmentation fault.

bug.short_desc: VUL-0: CVE-2021-20197: binutils: race window allows users to own arbitrary files

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2021-20197
There is an open race window when writing output in the following utilities in GNU binutils version 2.35 and earlier: ar, objcopy, strip, ranlib. When these utilities are run as a privileged user (presumably as part of a script updating binaries across different users), an unprivileged user can trick these utilities into getting ownership of arbitrary files through a symlink.
References: https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=26945 https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1913743 http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2021-20197

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2021-3487: binutils: excessive debug section size can cause excessive memory consumption in bfd's dwarf2.c read_section()

long_desc.thetext:
rh#1947111
read_section() in dwarf2.c of BFD could cause excessive memory consumption when handling corrupt DWARF debug sections. This could lead to an impact to system availability, denial of service, and/or a crash in applications linked with the BFD library's DWARF functionality if they parse files from untrusted sources.
Reference: https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=26946
Upstream patch commit: https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;h=647cebce12a6b0a26960220caff96ff38978cf24
References: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1947111 http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2021-3487 https://access.redhat.com/security/cve/CVE-2021-3487

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2021-20284: binutils: Heap-based buffer overflow in _bfd_elf_slurp_secondary_reloc_section in elf.c

long_desc.thetext:
rh#1937784
A flaw was found in GNU Binutils 2.35.1. There is a heap-based buffer overflow in _bfd_elf_slurp_secondary_reloc_section in elf.c because the number of symbols is not caculated correctly.
Upstream bug:
https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=26931
References: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1937784 http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2021-20284

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2017-16827: binutils: The aout_get_external_symbols function in aoutx.h in libbfd could exploited leading to a remote denial of service

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2017-16827
The aout_get_external_symbols function in aoutx.h in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.29.1, allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (slurp_symtab invalid free and application crash) or possibly have unspecified other impact via a crafted ELF file.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2017-16827 http://people.canonical.com/~ubuntu-security/cve/2017/CVE-2017-16827.html http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2017-16827 https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;h=0301ce1486b1450f219202677f30d0fa97335419 https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=22306

bug.short_desc: VUL-0: CVE-2017-16831: binutils: missing validation in coffgen.c in libbfd could lead to remote denial of service

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2017-16831
coffgen.c in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.29.1, does not validate the symbol count, which allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (integer overflow and application crash, or excessive memory allocation) or possibly have unspecified other impact via a crafted PE file.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2017-16831 http://people.canonical.com/~ubuntu-security/cve/2017/CVE-2017-16831.html http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2017-16831 https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=22385 https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;h=6cee897971d4d7cd37d2a686bb6d2aa3e759c8ca
this one is exploitable. Due to the integer overflow the allocation can be too small for the data written
please submit this one for SUSE:SLE-10-SP3:Update SUSE:SLE-11-SP1:Update:Teradata SUSE:SLE-11-SP4:Update SUSE:SLE-12:Update SUSE:SLE-15:Update Thank you

bug.short_desc: VUL-0: CVE-2017-15996: binutils: elfcomm.c in readelf allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2017-15996
elfcomm.c in readelf in GNU Binutils 2.29 and possible older versions, allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (excessive memory allocation) or possibly have unspecified other impact via a crafted ELF file that triggers a "buffer overflow on fuzzed archive header," related to an uninitialized variable, an improper conditional jump, and the get_archive_member_name, process_archive_index_and_symbols, and setup_archive functions.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2017-15996 http://www.cvedetails.com/cve/CVE-2017-15996/ http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2017-15996 https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;h=d91f0b20e561e326ee91a09a76206257bde8438b https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=22361

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2017-9755: binutils: DoS in opcodes/i386-dis.c that does not consider the number of registers for bnd mode

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2017-9755
opcodes/i386-dis.c in GNU Binutils 2.28 does not consider the number of registers for bnd mode, which allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (buffer overflow and application crash) or possibly have unspecified other impact via a crafted binary file, as demonstrated by mishandling of this file during "objdump -D" execution.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2017-9755 http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2017-9755 https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=21594

Reproducer output is a bit inconclusive.
#> valgrind objdump -D testcase.cve-2017-9755 ... ... ==3362== ERROR SUMMARY: 10000000 errors from 2 contexts (suppressed: 0 from 0)
Upstream Fix: https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;h=0d96e4df4812c3bad77c229dfef47a9bc115ac12
Low prio, not remotely exploitable.

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2017-8392: binutils: libbfd: objdump segfault - null pointer dereferencing (_bfd_dwarf2_find_nearest_line function)

long_desc.thetext:
Ref: https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2017-8392 ==================================================== Description
The Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.28, is vulnerable to an invalid read of size 8 because of missing a check to determine whether symbols are NULL in the _bfd_dwarf2_find_nearest_line function. This vulnerability causes programs that conduct an analysis of binary programs using the libbfd library, such as objdump, to crash.
Source: MITRE Last Modified: 05/01/2017 ====================================================
Hyperlink
[1] https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=21409
[2] https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;h=97e83a100aa8250be783304bfe0429761c6e6b6b (see https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=21409#c2)
(open-)SUSE: https://software.opensuse.org/package/binutils
2.28 (TW, official repo) 2.26.1 (42.{1,2}, official repo)
Created attachment 723322 21409_upstream_crash_info
Created attachment 723323 21409_upstream_crash_info_additional

QA REPRODUCER:
valgrind objdump -SD bug_7
should not show:
==13334== Invalid read of size 1 ==13334== at 0x54113F0: bfd_getl32 (in /usr/lib64/libbfd-2.23.1.so) ==13334== by 0x54249CC: ??? (in /usr/lib64/libbfd-2.23.1.so)
I can not match the patch to the old code though.

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2017-8393: binutils: libbfd: global-buffer-overflow in objcopy (SHT_REL/SHR_RELA sections)

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 723325 21412_upstream_crash_info
Ref: https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2017-8393 =================================================== Description
The Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.28, is vulnerable to a global buffer over-read error because of an assumption made by code that runs for objcopy and strip, that SHT_REL/SHR_RELA sections are always named starting with a .rel/.rela prefix. This vulnerability causes programs that conduct an analysis of binary programs using the libbfd library, such as objcopy and strip, to crash. ===================================================
Hyperlink
[1] https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=21412
[2] https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;h=bce964aa6c777d236fbd641f2bc7bb931cfe4bf3 (see https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=21412#c3)
(open-)SUSE: https://software.opensuse.org/package/binutils
2.28 (TW, official repo) 2.26.1 (42.{1,2}, official repo)
I cant get it to crash. it probably reads over a buffer, but valgrind does not see it at least, perhaps it really need ASAN to crash.

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2018-18483: binutils: The get_count function provided by libiberty allows attackers to cause a denial of service or other unspecified impact

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2018-18483 The get_count function in cplus-dem.c in GNU libiberty, as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.31, allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (malloc called with the result of an integer-overflowing calculation) or possibly have unspecified other impact via a crafted string, as demonstrated by c++filt.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2018-18483 http://www.cvedetails.com/cve/CVE-2018-18483/

bug.short_desc: VUL-0: CVE-2017-6965: binutils: readelf in GNU Binutils heap-based buffer overflow

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2017-6965
readelf in GNU Binutils 2.28 writes to illegal addresses while processing corrupt input files containing symbol-difference relocations, leading to a heap-based buffer overflow.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2017-6965 http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2017-6965 https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=21137
Blaeh, useless automatic fuzzer finds. Fixed in devel:gcc, as well as a collection of other sec fixes as well.
This is an autogenerated message for OBS integration: This bug (1029909) was mentioned in https://build.opensuse.org/request/show/480883 Factory / binutils

Hi, thank you for the quick response!
However the affected code, may exist in SLE codestreams. For example the commit https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;h=03f7786e2f440b9892b1c34a58fb26222ce1b493 AFAICS should/could be applied as well to SLE-12* codestreams
Could you please check which other codestreams are affected?
P.S: today we received some new issues from binutils, probably somebody still running his fuzzer and we may receive more related issues. To help us to keep track of all issues, I'm adding all issues in a tracker bug: https://bugzilla.suse.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1030295
This is an autogenerated message for OBS integration: This bug (1029909) was mentioned in https://build.opensuse.org/request/show/533970 Factory / binutils

thanks.

rh#1956423
A flaw was discovered in GNU libiberty, as distributed in GNU Binutils version 2.36. A crafted file can cause a stack-based buffer overflow in demangle_path() in rust-demangle.c.
Reference: https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/binutils/+bug/1925348

Created attachment 838837 bison_crash_quotearg_buffer_restyled

bug.short_desc: VUL-0: CVE-2020-24240: bison: use-after-free via crafted input file containing a NULL byte can lead to DoS

Nonsensical script kiddie CVE. This can't lead to system crashes or DoSes, it's a normal bug on broken unrealistic input. Anyway, taking for eventual fixing.

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2020-35448: binutils: heap-based buffer over-read in bfd_getl_signed_32() in libbfd.c

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2020-35448
An issue was discovered in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.35.1. A heap-based buffer over-read can occur in bfd_getl_signed_32 in libbfd.c because sh_entsize is not validated in _bfd_elf_slurp_secondary_reloc_section in elf.c.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2020-35448 http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2020-35448 https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=26574 https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;h=8642dafaef21aa6747cec01df1977e9c52eb4679 https://security.netapp.com/advisory/ntap-20210129-0008/

A flaw was found in binutils' readelf program. bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2016-6131: binutils: libiberty demangler segfaults

long_desc.thetext:
+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #987552 +++
https://gcc.gnu.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=71696
Another vulnerability in GNU Libiberty was found that impacts the security of binary analysis tools, such as Valgrind, GDB, Binutils (e.g., objdump, nm, ..), Gcov, or other LibBFD-based tools. An attacker might modify a program binary such that it executes malicious code upon *analysis* of the binary (e.g., to find whether it is malicious in the first place) or during the attempt to reverse-engineer an untrusted binary.
Workaround: Until the patches propagate to the vulnerable tools, switch off default demangling! E.g., $ echo "set demangle-style none" >> ~/.gdbinit $ echo "--demangle=no" >> ~/.valgrindrc
A stackoverflow in the libiberty demangler causes its host application to crash on a tainted branch instruction. The problem is caused by a self-reference in a mangled type string that is "remembered" for later reference. This leads to an infinite recursion during the demangling. * GDB exploitable classifies the stack overflow as exploitable. * Bug Report: https://gcc.gnu.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=71696 * Patch under review: https://gcc.gnu.org/ml/gcc-patches/2016-06/msg02030.html
From patch submission:
The attached patch fixes the stack overflow in the demangler due to cycles in the references of “remembered” mangled types (https://gcc.gnu.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=71696).
The methods demangle_signature and do_arg in cplus-dem.c allow to “remember” mangled type names that can later be referenced and will also be demangled. The method demangle_args demangles those types following any references. So, if there is a cycle in the referencing (or in the simplest case a self-reference), the method enters infinite recursion.
The patch tracks the mangled types that are currently being demangled in a new variable called work->proctypevec. If a referenced type is currently being demangled, the demangling is marked as not successful.
Bootstrapped and regression tested on x86_64-pc-linux-gnu. Test case added to libiberty/testsuite/demangler-expected and checked PR71696 is resolved.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2016-6131 http://seclists.org/oss-sec/2016/q2/633 http://people.canonical.com/~ubuntu-security/cve/2016/CVE-2016-6131.html
Security impact of this is marginal. Not requesting an update, may be fixed with a future maintenance update.
bugbot adjusting priority

bug.short_desc: binutils gold contains indeterminism

long_desc.thetext:
This was noticed in the build for project SUSE:Maintenance:13942, which contains a harmless patch relative to SUSE:Maintenance:12681 from before. The testresults for gold are different:
FAIL: bootstrap-test-r ====================== ld1-r ld2-r differ: char 645, line 1 FAIL bootstrap-test-r (exit status: 1)
The reason for this fail is a difference in the order of symbols in the symbol table of an .o files generated from libgold.a via --whole-archive:
% cd build-dir/gold % /home/abuild/rpmbuild/BUILD/binutils-2.32/build-dir/gold/ld-new -o bla-new.o -r --whole-archive libgold.a % /home/abuild/rpmbuild/BUILD/binutils-2.32/build-dir/gold/ld1 -o bla1.o -r --whole-archive libgold.a
% strings -a bla-new.o > a % strings -a bla1.o > b % diff a b --- a 2020-02-21 14:59:16.000000000 +0000 +++ b 2020-02-21 14:59:21.000000000 +0000 @@ -158144,7 +158144,6 @@ _ZN4gold15General_options16Struct_strip_ _ZN4gold15General_options20Struct_rosegment_gapD1Ev _ZTVN4gold15General_options20Struct_rosegment_gapE _ZN4gold15General_options20Struct_rosegment_gapD2Ev -_ZN4gold15General_options19Struct_no_rosegmentD1Ev _ZN4gold17Sized_relobj_incrILi64ELb0EE20do_section_addralignEj _ZN4gold17Sized_relobj_incrILi64ELb0EE18do_section_addressEj _ZN4gold17Sized_relobj_incrILi64ELb0EE18do_section_entsizeEj @@ -159028,6 +159027,7 @@ _ZN4gold10Binary_divD1Ev _ZN4gold10Binary_divD2Ev _ZN4gold10Binary_modD1Ev _ZN4gold10Binary_modD2Ev +_ZN4gold15General_options19Struct_no_rosegmentD1Ev _ZN4gold10Binary_addD1Ev _ZN4gold15General_options19Struct_no_rosegmentD2Ev _ZN4gold10Binary_addD2Ev @@ -159580,7 +159580,6 @@ _ZN4gold15Dwarf_line_info13one_addr2line _ZN4gold21Sized_dwarf_line_infoILi64ELb1EEC1EPNS_6ObjectEj _ZN4gold21Sized_dwarf_line_infoILi64ELb1EEC2EPNS_6ObjectEj _ZN4gold21Sized_dwarf_line_infoILi64ELb1EE18read_line_mappingsEj -_ZN4gold21Sized_dwarf_line_infoILi32ELb1EEC1EPNS_6ObjectEj _ZN4gold17Sized_incr_dynobjILi32ELb1EE20do_section_addralignEj _ZNSt8_Rb_treeIlSt4pairIKlmESt10_Select1stIS2_ESt4lessIlESaIS2_EE8_M_eraseEPSt13_Rb_tree_nodeIS2_E _ZNK4gold7Archive11do_filenameB5cxx11Ev @@ -159760,6 +159759,7 @@ _ZN4gold21Sized_dwarf_line_infoILi32ELb1 _ZNK4gold12Sized_relobjILi32ELb1EE24do_output_section_offsetEj _ZNK4gold11Read_relocs8get_nameB5cxx11Ev _ZNK4gold7Archive16interpret_headerEPKNS0_14Archive_headerElPNSt7__cxx1112basic_stringIcSt11char_traitsIcESaIcEEEPl +_ZN4gold21Sized_dwarf_line_infoILi32ELb1EEC1EPNS_6ObjectEj _ZNK4gold12Sized_relobjILi32ELb0EE24do_output_section_offsetEj _ZNK4gold17Gc_process_relocs8get_nameB5cxx11Ev _ZN4gold7Archive6arfmagE @@ -160776,6 +160776,7 @@ _ZNSt6vectorIN4gold11Descriptors15Open_d _ZN4gold25Global_got_offset_visitorILi32ELb1EED0Ev _ZNSt6vectorINSt8__detail14_Node_iteratorISt4pairIKN4gold19Stringpool_templateItE7HashkeyEmELb0ELb1EEESaIS9_EE17_M_realloc_insertIJS9_EEEvN9__gnu_cxx17__normal_iteratorIPS9_SB_EEDpOT_ _ZN4gold11Descriptors4openEiPKcii +_ZN4gold24Local_got_offset_visitorILi64ELb0EED0Ev _ZNSt10_HashtableIN4gold19Stringpool_templateIjE7HashkeyESt4pairIKS3_mESaIS6_ENSt8__detail10_Select1stENS2_13Stringpool_eqENS2_15Stringpool_hashENS8_18_Mod_range_hashingENS8_20_Default_ranged_hashENS8_20_Prime_rehash_policyENS8_17_Hashtable_traitsILb1ELb0ELb1EEEE9_M_rehashEmRKm _ZN4gold15Initialize_lock10initializeEv _ZN4gold19Stringpool_templateIjE7reserveEj @@ -161736,7 +161737,6 @@ _ZTVN4gold15General_options15Struct_no_r _ZN4gold21Sized_dwarf_line_infoILi32ELb0EE18read_line_mappingsEj _ZTVN4gold15General_options16Struct_rosegmentE _ZN4gold21Sized_dwarf_line_infoILi32ELb1EE18read_line_mappingsEj -_ZN4gold24Local_got_offset_visitorILi64ELb0EED0Ev _ZN4gold25Global_got_offset_visitorILi64ELb0EED0Ev _ZN4gold24Local_got_offset_visitorILi64ELb1EED0Ev _ZN4gold25Global_got_offset_visitorILi64ELb1EED0Ev
(ld1-r, ld2, ld2-r, ld3 and ld4 generate the same .o like ld1, which is different from the one generated by ld-new)
So, gold contains an indeterminism, which is now triggered, either because of the change from the build system between the two maint repos, or because of the patch (but not because of functionality of it). We should investigate this, but it shouldn't hold up the maintenance update.

FWIW, the symbols in question are weaks, and have the property that with a gold linked by ld.bfd (i.e. the normal g++ build, i.e. ld-new) they are at the beginning of a block of symbols, while with a gold linked with gold (i.e. the ld1... binaries) they are at the end of that block. E.g.:
% ./ld-new -Map map-new.txt -o bla-new.o -r --whole-archive libgold.a % ./ld1 -Map map-1.txt -o bla1.o -r --whole-archive libgold.a % readelf -sW bla-new.o > a % readelf -sW bla1.o > b % diff -up a b ... - 14910: 0000000000000000 34 FUNC WEAK DEFAULT 7573 _ZN4gold15General_options19Struct_no_rosegmentD1Ev - 14911: 0000000000000000 28 FUNC WEAK DEFAULT 3216 _ZN4gold17Sized_relobj_incrILi64ELb0EE20do_section_addralignEj ... - 15793: 0000000000000000 50 FUNC WEAK DEFAULT 1884 _ZN4gold10Binary_modD2Ev + 14910: 0000000000000000 28 FUNC WEAK DEFAULT 3216 _ZN4gold17Sized_relobj_incrILi64ELb0EE20do_section_addralignEj ... + 15793: 0000000000000000 34 FUNC WEAK DEFAULT 7573 _ZN4gold15General_options19Struct_no_rosegmentD1Ev 15794: 0000000000000000 50 FUNC WEAK DEFAULT 1883 _ZN4gold10Binary_addD1Ev ...
(Note how _ZN4gold15General_options19Struct_no_rosegmentD1Ev moved from the beginning of the '-' block to the end of the '+' block, and all other symbols moved one upwards). So possibly the sorting that gold does with weak symbols (for their aliases) isn't completely stable.
