bug.short_desc: gdb.convenience_variable does not appear to understand "arg0"

long_desc.thetext: (gdb) define foo Redefine command "foo"? (y or n) y Type commands for definition of "foo". End with a line saying just "end". >set $copyarg0 = $arg0 >python >print ("python thinks arg0 is", gdb.convenience_variable("arg0")) >print ("python thinks copyarg0 is", gdb.convenience_variable("copyarg0")) >end >end (gdb) foo "teststring" python thinks arg0 is None python thinks copyarg0 is "teststring" (gdb) show version GNU gdb (GDB; openSUSE Leap 15.1) 10.1

The "$arg0" is not a convenience variable (though it starts with a '$' like a convenience variable, so that is confusing): ... $ gdb -q a.out Reading symbols from a.out... (gdb) define foo Type commands for definition of "foo". End with a line saying just "end". >print $arg0 >show convenience >end (gdb) foo 1 $1 = 1 $_gdb_minor = 1 ... <no sign of $arg0> ... (gdb) ...
So this: ... >pyton ... >print ("python thinks arg0 is", gdb.convenience_variable("arg0")) ... gdb) foo "teststring" python thinks arg0 is None ... looks correct.
Instead, arg0 is a user command entity, which is substituted into each line of the user program when being interpreted.
Doing this: ... >python ... starts up a different interpreter, where arg0 is not handled specially. That could be considered a improvement opportunity, but that's not specific to openSUSE gdb.
BTW, note that this seems to work: ... $ gdb -q a.out Reading symbols from a.out... (gdb) define foo Type commands for definition of "foo". End with a line saying just "end". >python print ($arg0) >end (gdb) foo 1 1 ...

info gdb page 15.4.10.3 Additions to Ada says A name starting with '$' is a convenience variable (*note Convenience Vars::) or a machine register
Maybe that's a mistake, but it's a clear statement that $arg0 is a convenience variable. Most other built-in $-something variables are convenience variables, although machine register names are specifically excepted.
"but that's not specific to openSUSE gdb"
I didn't suggest that it was. The bug reporting instructions for openSUSE gdb says to report gdb bugs on the openSUSE bugzilla, so I did that. If I should report gdb bugs somewhere else, the bug reporting instructions are wrong.
python print ($arg0) works because the whole line is evaluated by the gdb command decoder before passing it to python, so Python doesn't see the $arg0. The failure that I reported was with the Python function gdb.convenience_variable("arg0"). If $arg0 isn't a convenience variable, how do I access it from a python function, apart from the workaround that I suggested?

bug.short_desc: VUL-0: CVE-2020-35496: binutils: multiple NULL pointer dereferences in bfd module due to not checking return value of bfd_malloc

long_desc.thetext:
rh#1911444
GNU Binutils before 2.34 has multiple NULL pointer deference bugs in bfd module due to not checking return value of bfd_malloc. This bug allows attackers to cause a denial of service.
Reference: https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=25308
References: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1911444 http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2020-35496 https://access.redhat.com/security/cve/CVE-2020-35496

bug.short_desc: VUL-0: CVE-2020-35495: binutils: NULL pointer dereference in bfd_pef_parse_symbols function in bfd/pef.c

long_desc.thetext:
rh#1911441
GNU Binutils before 2.34 has a NULL pointer deference vulnerability in function bfd_pef_parse_symbols (file bfd/pef.c) which could allow attackers to cause a denial of service.
Reference: https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=25306
References: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1911441 http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2020-35495 https://access.redhat.com/security/cve/CVE-2020-35495

bug.short_desc: dsymutil segfault on ELF hello world

long_desc.thetext:
When compiling an ELF hello world: ... $ gcc ~/hello.c -g ... such that I have: ... $ file a.out a.out: ELF 64-bit LSB executable, x86-64, version 1 (SYSV), dynamically linked, interpreter /lib64/l, BuildID[sha1]=06eb5c7624f5b61bebacdb685c355015effa8f85, for GNU/Linux 3.2.0, with debug_info, not stripped ... and using dsymutil on that file, I get: ... $ dsymutil a.out Stack dump: 0. Program arguments: dsymutil a.out #0 0x00007fa0393d229d llvm::sys::PrintStackTrace(llvm::raw_ostream&) (/usr/bin/../lib64/libLLVM.so.10+0x9af29d) #1 0x00007fa0393cfbc0 llvm::sys::RunSignalHandlers() (/usr/bin/../lib64/libLLVM.so.10+0x9acbc0) #2 0x00007fa0393d2932 (/usr/bin/../lib64/libLLVM.so.10+0x9af932) #3 0x00007fa0382ca5a0 __restore_rt (/lib64/libc.so.6+0x395a0) #4 0x0000000000410105 std::__uniq_ptr_impl<llvm::dsymutil::DebugMap, std::default_delete<llvm::dsymutil::DebugMap> >::_M_ptr() const /usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux/7/../../../../include/c++/7/bits/unique_ptr.h:147:42 #5 0x0000000000410105 std::unique_ptr<llvm::dsymutil::DebugMap, std::default_delete<llvm::dsymutil::DebugMap> >::get() const /usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux/7/../../../../include/c++/7/bits/unique_ptr.h:332:21 #6 0x0000000000410105 std::unique_ptr<llvm::dsymutil::DebugMap, std::default_delete<llvm::dsymutil::DebugMap> >::operator->() const /usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux/7/../../../../include/c++/7/bits/unique_ptr.h:326:9 #7 0x0000000000410105 _init /usr/src/debug/llvm10-10.0.1-lp152.17.9.x86_64/build/../tools/dsymutil/dsymutil.cpp:566:11 #8 0x00007fa0382b534a __libc_start_main /usr/src/debug/glibc-2.26-lp152.26.3.1.x86_64/csu/../csu/libc-start.c:342:0 #9 0x000000000040d71a _init /home/abuild/rpmbuild/BUILD/glibc-2.26/csu/../sysdeps/x86_64/start.S:122:0 Segmentation fault (core dumped) ...
segfault happens here: ... Thread 1 "dsymutil" received signal SIGSEGV, Segmentation fault. main (argc=2, argv=<optimized out>) at ../tools/dsymutil/dsymutil.cpp:566 566 if (Map->begin() == Map->end()) ... while Map is: ... (gdb) p Map $4 = std::unique_ptr<llvm::dsymutil::DebugMap> = {get() = Cannot access memory at address 0x100000000 ...
AFAICT, Map is invalid because it's created by: ... for (auto &Map : *DebugMapPtrsOrErr) { ... while DebugMapPtrsOrErr.HasError is true: ... (gdb) p DebugMapPtrsOrErr $2 = {static isRef = false, {TStorage = { buffer = "\000\000\000\000\001\000\000\000\340q\357\362\377\177\000\000Sv\375\362\377\177\000"}, ErrorStorage = { buffer = "\000\000\000\000\001\000\000\000\340q\357\362\377\177\000"}}, HasError = true} ...
There is error checking in the source: ... auto DebugMapPtrsOrErr = parseDebugMap(InputFile, Options.Archs, Options.LinkOpts.PrependPath, Options.PaperTrailWarnings, Options.LinkOpts.Verbose, Options.InputIsYAMLDebugMap);
if (auto EC = DebugMapPtrsOrErr.getError()) { WithColor::error() << "cannot parse the debug map for '" << InputFile << "': " << EC.message() << '\n'; return 1; } ...
But that doesn't seem to trigger: ... (gdb) p DebugMapPtrsOrErr $10 = {static isRef = false, {TStorage = { buffer = "\000\000\000\000\001\000\000\000\340q\357\362\377\177\000\000Sv\375\362\377\177\000"}, ErrorStorage = { buffer = "\000\000\000\000\001\000\000\000\340q\357\362\377\177\000"}}, HasError = true} (gdb) 516 if (auto EC = DebugMapPtrsOrErr.getError()) { (gdb) s llvm::ErrorOr<std::vector<std::unique_ptr<llvm::dsymutil::DebugMap, std::default_delete<llvm::dsymutil::DebugMap> >, std::allocator<std::unique_ptr<llvm::dsymutil::DebugMap, std::default_delete<llvm::dsymutil::DebugMap> > > > >::getError (this=0x7fffffffd4c8) at ../include/llvm/Support/ErrorOr.h:160 160 return HasError ? *getErrorStorage() : std::error_code(); (gdb) 516 if (auto EC = DebugMapPtrsOrErr.getError()) { (gdb) std::error_code::operator bool (this=<optimized out>) at /usr/lib64/gcc/x86_64-suse-linux/7/../../../../include/c++/7/system_error:192 192 { return _M_value != 0; } (gdb) main (argc=2, argv=<optimized out>) at ../tools/dsymutil/dsymutil.cpp:516 516 if (auto EC = DebugMapPtrsOrErr.getError()) { (gdb) 524 Options.LinkOpts.NumDebugMaps = DebugMapPtrsOrErr->size(); (gdb) ...
So, my current guess is a miscompilation.
Version info: ... $ dsymutil --version LLVM (http://llvm.org/): LLVM version 10.0.1 Optimized build. Default target: x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu Host CPU: skylake ...

Reproduced on tumbleweed.
Also reproduced on tumbleweed with llvm7 package.

Build llvm trunk on leap 15.2 at current commit 396e7f454893 "[mlir][SCFToGPU] LaunchOp propagate optional attributes", using -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Debug.
Did not reproduce.

(In reply to Tom de Vries from comment #2) > Build llvm trunk on leap 15.2 at current commit 396e7f454893 > "[mlir][SCFToGPU] LaunchOp propagate optional attributes", using > -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Debug. > > Did not reproduce.
Also tried with -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=RelWithDebInfo, did not reproduce.

(In reply to Tom de Vries from comment #3) > (In reply to Tom de Vries from comment #2) > > Build llvm trunk on leap 15.2 at current commit 396e7f454893 > > "[mlir][SCFToGPU] LaunchOp propagate optional attributes", using > > -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Debug. > > > > Did not reproduce. > > Also tried with -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=RelWithDebInfo, did not reproduce.
Checked out tag llvmorg-10.0.1 and build with -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=RelWithDebInfo, reproduced.

Fixed by: ... commit ef87f69ec538ccfe7d68b6d03125e7636e859ace (HEAD) Author: Greg Clayton <gclayton@fb.com> Date: Fri Mar 6 14:59:41 2020 -0800
Fix a copy and paste error that would cause a crash.
Summary: The wrong variable was being checked for an error, which mean a llvm::Error went unchecked and crashes dsymutil. Discovered this when trying to feed an ELF file to "dsymutil - -update" and running into the crash.
Reviewers: aprantl, JDevlieghere
Subscribers: llvm-commits
Tags: #llvm
Differential Revision: https://reviews.llvm.org/D75777
diff --git a/llvm/tools/dsymutil/MachODebugMapParser.cpp b/llvm/tools/dsymutil/MachODebugMa pParser.cpp index 3292e9485725..818b338d800d 100644 --- a/llvm/tools/dsymutil/MachODebugMapParser.cpp +++ b/llvm/tools/dsymutil/MachODebugMapParser.cpp @@ -382,7 +382,7 @@ ErrorOr<std::vector<std::unique_ptr<DebugMap>>> MachODebugMapParse r::parse() {
auto Objects = ObjectEntry->getObjectsAs<MachOObjectFile>(); if (!Objects) { - return errorToErrorCode(ObjectEntry.takeError()); + return errorToErrorCode(Objects.takeError()); }
std::vector<std::unique_ptr<DebugMap>> Results; ...

bug.short_desc: addr2line DWARF error since opensuse patch

long_desc.thetext:
I'm using backtrace from execinfo.h in connection with /usr/bin/addr2line. This worked like a charm for as long as I can remember. Since recently this no longer works, even though the code hasn't changed. Now there is just this output: /usr/bin/addr2line: DWARF error: could not find variable specification at offset a2b2 /usr/bin/addr2line: DWARF error: could not find variable specification at offset a2bf /usr/bin/addr2line: DWARF error: could not find variable specification at offset a2cc /usr/bin/addr2line: DWARF error: could not find variable specification at offset a2d9 /usr/bin/addr2line: DWARF error: could not find variable specification at offset a2e6 /usr/bin/addr2line: DWARF error: could not find variable specification at offset a2f3 /usr/bin/addr2line: DWARF error: could not find variable specification at offset a300 /usr/bin/addr2line: DWARF error: could not find variable specification at offset a30d /usr/bin/addr2line: DWARF error: could not find variable specification at offset a31a /usr/bin/addr2line: DWARF error: could not find variable specification at offset a327 /usr/bin/addr2line: DWARF error: could not find variable specification at offset a334 /usr/bin/addr2line: DWARF error: could not find variable specification at offset a341 /usr/bin/addr2line: DWARF error: could not find variable specification at offset 2593 /usr/bin/addr2line: DWARF error: could not find variable specification at offset 260d
If you search on the internet for this error then you'll find that it is a known regression which has already been fixes at places. Just not yet for opensuse 15.1.
I have these binutils patches installed: zypper patches | grep -i binutils Main Update Repository | openSUSE-2019-2432 | security | moderate | --- | applied | - | Security update for binutils Main Update Repository | openSUSE-2020-1790 | security | moderate | --- | applied | 2020-11-02 | Security update for binutils Main Update Repository | openSUSE-2020-267 | recommended | moderate | --- | applied | - | Recommended update for binutils
I don't like those patches, but yast2 or zypper don't give me a user friendly way to remove them. If I could just get the original binutils back then I'd be fine. It's quite troublesome as now my 15.1 system has become more or less useless as a development platform.

I suppose you mean
https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=26520
Sigh, this was fixed right after the cut-off date for our binutils update :-/ I'll see if I can stop the running update and still squeeze this one in.
Sigh, this was fixed right after the cut-off date for our binutils update :-/ I'll see if I can stop the running update and still squeeze this one in.

bug.short_desc: LD from binutils 2.33.1 is broken on aarch64

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 824949 tensorflow full build log
While building Tensorflow for Factory:ARM we get the following error:
[20116s] /usr/bin/gcc -shared -o bazel-out/aarch64-opt/bin/tensorflow/python/_pywrap_tensorflow_internal.so '-Wl,-rpath,$ORIGIN/../../_solib_aarch64/_U_S_Stensorflow_Spython_C_Upywrap_Utensorflow_Uinternal.so___Utensorflow' -Lbazel-out/aarch64-opt/bin/_solib_aarch64/_U_S_Stensorflow_Spython_C_Upywrap_Utensorflow_Uinternal.so___Utensorflow -Wl,--version-script bazel-out/aarch64-opt/bin/tensorflow/python/pywrap_tensorflow_internal_versionscript.lds '-Wl,-rpath,$ORIGIN/,-rpath,$ORIGIN/..' -Wl,-soname,_pywrap_tensorflow_internal.so -Wl,-no-as-needed -Wl,-z,relro,-z,now -B/usr/bin -B/usr/bin -pass-exit-codes -Wl,--gc-sections -Wl,@bazel-out/aarch64-opt/bin/tensorflow/python/_pywrap_tensorflow_internal.so-2.params) [20116s] /usr/bin/ld: can not size stub section: invalid operation [20116s] /usr/bin/ld: linker stubs: file class ELFCLASSNONE incompatible with ELFCLASS64 [20116s] /usr/bin/ld: final link failed: file in wrong format [20116s] collect2: error: ld returned 1 exit status
Building for released Tumbleweed is fine. Major diffs are: * binutils 2.32 > 2.33.1: https://build.opensuse.org/request/show/748099 * kernel 5.3.8 > 5.3.12 * java-1_8_0-openjdk 1.8.0.222 > 1.8.0.232
binutils 2.33 got lots of aarch64 update and the error is from ld, so this is where my suspicions go.

I tried to build this package with an overlay which replaces binutils 2.33.1, by previous version 2.32 and the problem is gone. So, this is really related to binutils 2.33.1 update. Maybe some deps need to be rebuild?

Looks like gcc9 and glibc weren't rebuilt after the binutils update, so I guess thats part of the problem..
I'll trigger a full rebuild, hasn't been done in many months..

Same is happening in rustc:
http://pastebin.nue.suse.com/23631/src

This was a transient error, but I submitted the fix too late to Factory (only now sr#751060). Now we might have the problem that binutils can't build itself anymore on Factory:ARM, in which case someone needs to play games with injecting an working binutils into the tree.

@Michal, thanks for the fix.
For the record, upstream bug is https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=25210
I sidestepped the factory review process and linked this fix directly into Factory:ARM. Lets see if we can recover quickly.

Assigning to Micha. Note there is feedback in the upstream bugreport. could you please also add the bugreference to the changes entry?
We were able to recover bootstrap of Factory:ARM with that binutils, thanks a lot!

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2019-17450: binutils: denial of service in find_abstract_instance in dwarf2.c

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2019-17450
find_abstract_instance in dwarf2.c in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.32, allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (infinite recursion and application crash) via a crafted ELF file.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2019-17450 http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2019-17450 https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=25078

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2019-17451: binutils: an integer overflow leading to a SEGV in _bfd_dwarf2_find_nearest_line in dwarf2.c

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2019-17451
An issue was discovered in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.32. It is an integer overflow leading to a SEGV in _bfd_dwarf2_find_nearest_line in dwarf2.c, as demonstrated by nm.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2019-17451 http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2019-17451 https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;h=336bfbeb1848f4b9558456fdcf283ee8a32d7fd1 https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=25070

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2019-14444: binutils: apply_relocations in readelf.c in GNU Binutils 2.32 contains an integer overflow that allows attackers to trigger a write access violation (in byte_put_little_endian function in elfcomm.c) via an ELF file

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2019-14444
apply_relocations in readelf.c in GNU Binutils 2.32 contains an integer overflow that allows attackers to trigger a write access violation (in byte_put_little_endian function in elfcomm.c) via an ELF file, as demonstrated by readelf.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2019-14444 http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2019-14444 https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=24829
Created attachment 812275 CVE-2019-14444-binutils.patch

binutils is affected in the following code streams:
SUSE:SLE-11-SP1:Update:Teradata SUSE:SLE-11-SP3:Update SUSE:SLE-11-SP4:Update SUSE:SLE-12-SP5:Update SUSE:SLE-12:Update SUSE:SLE-15-SP1:Update SUSE:SLE-15:Update

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2019-12972: binutils: heap-based buffer over-read in _bfd_doprnt in bfd.c

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2019-12972
An issue was discovered in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.32. There is a heap-based buffer over-read in _bfd_doprnt in bfd.c because elf_object_p in elfcode.h mishandles an e_shstrndx section of type SHT_GROUP by omitting a trailing '\0' character.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2019-12972 http://people.canonical.com/~ubuntu-security/cve/2019/CVE-2019-12972.html http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2019-12972 https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=24689 https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;h=890f750a3b053532a4b839a2dd6243076de12031
This is an autogenerated message for IBS integration: This bug (1140126) was mentioned in https://build.suse.de/request/show/226504 SLE-15-SP1 / binutils

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2019-9074: binutils: out-of-bounds read leading to a SEGV in bfd_getl32 in libbfd.c, when called from

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2019-9074
An issue was discovered in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.32. It is an out-of-bounds read leading to a SEGV in bfd_getl32 in libbfd.c, when called from pex64_get_runtime_function in pei-x86_64.c.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2019-9074 https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=24235

bug.short_desc: VUL-0: CVE-2019-9075: binutils: heap-based buffer overflow in _bfd_archive_64_bit_slurp_armap in archive64.c.

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2019-9075
An issue was discovered in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.32. It is a heap-based buffer overflow in _bfd_archive_64_bit_slurp_armap in archive64.c.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2019-9075 https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=24236

Created attachment 797927 hbo
QA REPRODUCER:
size hbo
should not crash
This has been a high severity vulnerability for some time. Any update or plans for the patch?

This is a typical script-kiddie-fuzzes CVE, not anything worth a high priority. The NIST categorization of these is notoriously non-sensical.
We fix this type of CVEs with version updates of binutils, so the next one will contain a fix.

Thanks Michael for your prompt response and explanation of the severity from SUSE's standpoint. We understand that the NIST categorization and scoring can be off sometimes, but do see that SUSE is still listing this as a High severity vulnerability on the SUSE CVE page as well (https://www.suse.com/security/cve/CVE-2019-9075/). Do you have an estimation on when the binutils update expected to be released?
This is an autogenerated message for IBS integration: This bug (1126829) was mentioned in https://build.suse.de/request/show/226504 SLE-15-SP1 / binutils

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2019-9077: binutils: heap-based buffer overflow in process_mips_specific in readelf.c via a malformed MIPS option section.

long_desc.thetext:

bug.short_desc: VUL-0: CVE-2017-17121: binutils: Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd) allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2017-17121
The Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.29.1, allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (memory access violation) or possibly have unspecified other impact via a COFF binary in which a relocation refers to a location after the end of the to-be-relocated section.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2017-17121 http://people.canonical.com/~ubuntu-security/cve/2017/CVE-2017-17121.html http://www.cvedetails.com/cve/CVE-2017-17121/ http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2017-17121 https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;h=b23dc97fe237a1d9e850d7cbeee066183a00630b https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=22506

Created attachment 751732 QA Reproducer
SLE12> objdump -W perform_reloc
perform_reloc: file format pei-i386
Contents of the section:
00000000 ZERO terminator
objdump: perform_reloc: warning: illegal symbol index 131072 in relocs objdump: perform_reloc: warning: illegal symbol index 0 in relocs Segmentation fault (core dumped)

Upstream fix:
https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;h=b23dc97fe237a1d9e850d7cbeee066183a00630b
Unfortunately not only used for reads. Please submit for SUSE:SLE-10-SP3:Update SUSE:SLE-11-SP1:Update:Teradata SUSE:SLE-11-SP4:Update SUSE:SLE-12:Update Thank you
(In reply to Johannes Segitz from comment #3) ping, please submit

Hi Support, I have a customer who are focus on this CVE-2019-9075. I don't see any information about this CVE of SLES12SP5 on https://www.suse.com/security/cve/. Is SLES12 SP5 affected by this CVE? Is it a plan to merge it into SLES12sp5?
Thanks.

(In reply to Yingjun Ni from comment #5) > Hi Support, > I have a customer who are focus on this CVE-2019-9075. > I don't see any information about this CVE of SLES12SP5 on > https://www.suse.com/security/cve/. > Is SLES12 SP5 affected by this CVE? Is it a plan to merge it into SLES12sp5? > > Thanks.
sorry for the mistype, the customer is asking about CVE-2017-17121.
binutils 2.32 (contained in SLE12-SP5 currently) has this problem fixed. It was forgotten to be mentioned in the changes file :-(

(In reply to Michael Matz from comment #7) > binutils 2.32 (contained in SLE12-SP5 currently) has this problem fixed. > It was forgotten to be mentioned in the changes file :-(
ok, appreciated for your reply.

bug.short_desc: UUID_LE(0x66f0d379, 0xb4f3, 0x4074, 0xac, 0x43, 0x0d, 0x33, 0x18, 0xb7, 0x8c, 0xdb) not considered constant

long_desc.thetext:
static const uuid_le uuid_pmem = UUID_LE(0x66f0d379, 0xb4f3, 0x4074, 0xac, 0x43, 0x0d, 0x33, 0x18, 0xb7, 0x8c, 0xdb);
does not compile:
[ 56s] ../acpi.h:20:1: error: initializer element is not constant [ 56s] static const uuid_le uuid_pmem = UUID_LE(0x66f0d379, 0xb4f3, 0x4074, 0xac, 0x43, 0x0d,
https://build.opensuse.org/package/live_build_log/home:michals/ndctl/SLE_12_SP5/x86_64
note: this package is not needed in 12 SP5
however, uuid in particular and similar constructs in general are common so other packages may hit this issue

Created attachment 842855 preprocessed source of the failing file
gcc -std=gnu99 -DHAVE_CONFIG_H -I. -I.. -include ../config.h -DSYSCONFDIR=\""/etc"\" -DLIBEXECDIR=\""/usr/lib"\" -DPREFIX=\""/usr"\" -DNDCTL_MAN_PATH=\""/usr/share/man"\" -I../ndctl/lib -I../ndctl -I../ -I/usr/include/kmod -I/usr/include/uuid -I/usr/include/json-c -Wall -Wchar-subscripts -Wformat-security -Wmissing-declarations -Wmissing-prototypes -Wnested-externs -Wshadow -Wsign-compare -Wstrict-prototypes -Wtype-limits -Wmaybe-uninitialized -Wdeclaration-after-statement -Wunused-result -D_FORTIFY_SOURCE=2 -O2 -fvisibility=hidden -ffunction-sections -fdata-sections -fmessage-length=0 -grecord-gcc-switches -fstack-protector -O2 -Wall -D_FORTIFY_SOURCE=2 -funwind-tables -fasynchronous-unwind-tables -fstack-clash-protection -g -c -o create-nfit.o create-nfit.c In file included from create-nfit.c:25:0: ../acpi.h:20:1: error: initializer element is not constant static const uuid_le uuid_pmem = UUID_LE(0x66f0d379, 0xb4f3, 0x4074, 0xac, 0x43, 0x0d, ^
GCC 5 is the first non-affected release.

Fixed with r5-4232-g7278465e24b3d5a3:
re PR c/63567 (Linux kernel build error due to non-static initializers)
PR c/63567 * c-typeck.c (digest_init): Allow initializing objects with static storage duration with compound literals even in C99 and add pedwarn for it.
* gcc.dg/pr61096-1.c: Change dg-error into dg-warning. * gcc.dg/pr63567-1.c: New test. * gcc.dg/pr63567-2.c: New test.
From-SVN: r216416

Indeed.
> gcc-10 -S t.c -std=c99 -O2 -pedantic-errors t.c:4:35: error: initializer element is not constant [-Wpedantic] 4 | static const uuid_le uuid_pmem2 = (uuid_le){{ 0x0 }}; | ^
but fine without the (uuid_le) so it seems not using a compound literal but an initializer would be more standard conforming here.
Let me backport this to devel:gcc/gcc48 to be picked up in case we ever do another update for SLE12

attachment.desc: preprocessed source of the failing file

bug.short_desc: VUL-0: Intel CPU Jump Conditional Code (JCC) jump misprediction

long_desc.thetext:
(Slide 1) Issue:
Conditional Jumps (JCC) code can have their branch target get corrupted by merging the targets of two branches that happen due to alias within the branch predictor. This occurs when the branch predictor and DSB (Decoded Stream Buffer) get out of sync.
Impact:
Can result in unpredictable system behaviour, typically resulting from jumping to an incorrect location within given process address space and getting a #UD or #PF.
NOTE: impacts SKL-Family products only (no BDW , nor ICL)
Planned workaround:
Disable "CFLB" (Cross Fetch-Line Branch) ability to allocate into the DSB via MCU.
Mitigation included in SKX MCU (0x64) and CLX MCU (0x2b) and respective IPU 2019.2

(Slide 2)
JCC Erratum Workaround Effects
Applications benefitting from the decoded ICache can see degradations from switching to the legacy pipeline.
- workloads with smaller instruction cache footprint can have greater effects
Applications may experience variable performance from build to build
- Will change upon recompile and relink, which changes alignment from branches
Code generators can wrokaround most of the overhead introduced
- Keep branches/macro fused branches from crossing or ending on 32-byte boundaries

Rest of the slides:
https://gitlab.suse.de/security/spec2018/wikis/jcc-slides

Summary:
- MCU mitigates the issue, reduces performance a bit
- Speedups could be gained by adjusting code generation.
Note that for Skylake and Cascade Lake the MCU was already released, version 20190918.

This was published November 11.
https://www.intel.com/content/www/us/en/support/articles/000055650/processors/intel-xeon-processors.html
https://www.intel.com/content/dam/support/us/en/documents/processors/mitigations-jump-conditional-code-erratum.pdf

Jump Conditional Code Erratum Overview White Paper for Processors
Documentation
Content Type Product Information & Documentation
Article ID 000055650
Last Reviewed 11/08/2019
Starting with the second-generation Intel® Core™ Processors and Intel® Xeon® E3-1200 Series Processors (formerly codenamed Sandy Bridge) and later processor families, the Intel® microarchitecture introduces a microarchitectural structure called the Decoded ICache (also called the Decoded Streaming Buffer or DSB).
The Decoded ICache caches decoded instructions, called micro-ops (μops), coming out of the legacy decode pipeline. The next time the processor accesses the same code, the Decoded ICache provides the μops directly, speeding up program execution.
In some Intel® Processors, there's an erratum (SKX102) that may occur under complex microarchitectural conditions involving jump instructions that span across 64-byte boundaries (cross cache lines). A microcode update (MCU) can prevent this erratum.
For more information about this erratum including how to get the MCU, view the Mitigations for Jump Conditional Code Erratum White Paper.

So basically to summarize:
- the CPU Microcode update fixes the issue, but makes the code a bit slower - the compiler / binutils is supposed to make the code fast again by avoiding conditional jump instructions across 32byte boundaries.

According to the document it's all jumps, not just conditional ones. Microcode updates fix the security issue so this is a request for optimization that should go via Jira?
The document mentions -malign-branch-* and -mbranches-within-32B which neither are available in upstream gas at the very moment (but I guess HJ will commit in a second). Thus a requirement is probably to backport those to 2.32 and update binutils across products.
So far it is not clear if Intel requests this from us for older products. Need to ask Pragyan again.

bug.short_desc: [GCC9] miscompilation on vectorized division loop, leading to FP exception

long_desc.thetext:
A miscompile in ecc9 on aarch64 when -march=armv8.2-a+sve is used leads to an FPE. The issue doesn't occur when SVE isn't used: -march=armv8.2-a. Details and a repoducer can be found in the upstream bugzilla: https://gcc.gnu.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=96373
The issue occurred with OpenFOAM and is known by ARM to occur there: ARM had already fixed the same issue with LLVM.

The following workaround was shared: Set environment variable FOAM_SIGFPE=false before running OpenFOAM. This will disable catching the Floating-Point Exceptions (but may still result in NaN being returned from the affected functions).

bug.short_desc: VUL-0: CVE-2017-12459: binutils: bfd_mach_o_read_symtab_strtab function in bfd/mach-o.c allows remote attackers to cause an out of bounds heap write and possibly achieve code execution

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2017-12459
The bfd_mach_o_read_symtab_strtab function in bfd/mach-o.c in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.29 and earlier, allows remote attackers to cause an out of bounds heap write and possibly achieve code execution via a crafted mach-o file.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2017-12459 http://people.canonical.com/~ubuntu-security/cve/2017/CVE-2017-12459.html http://www.cvedetails.com/cve/CVE-2017-12459/
Upstream fix: https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;a=patch;h=8bdf0be19d2777565a8b1c88347f65d6a4b8c5fc

oob_write_mach_o_cache: file format mach-o-le oob_write_mach_o_cache architecture: aarch64, flags 0x00000010: HAS_SYMS start address 0x0000000000000000
objdump: bfd_mach_o_canonicalize_symtab: unable to load symbols Sections: Idx Name Size VMA LMA File off Algn SYMBOL TABLE: no symbols
Segmentation fault (core dumped)
not in the 2017 toolchain submission.
so this is one of the issues that remain and we would like to fix. We currently track this for SUSE:SLE-11-SP3:Update SUSE:SLE-11-SP4:Update Can you please submit there? Thank you

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2017-9054: libdwarf: _dwarf_decode_s_leb128_chk() a byte pointer is dereferenced just before it was checked for being in bounds

CVE-2017-9054

Fixed by cc37d6917011733d776ae228af4e5d6abe9613c1 in dwarf_leb.c. We don't have the check at all.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2017-9054 http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2017-9054

Fixed by cc37d6917011733d776ae228af4e5d6abe9613c1 in dwarf_form.c
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2017-9055 http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2017-9055

Also CVE-2017-9052. The new CVE system is total crap.
An issue, also known as DW201703-006, was discovered in libdwarf 2017-03-21. A heap-based buffer over-read in dwarf_formsdata() is due to a failure to check a pointer for being in bounds (in a few places in this function) and a failure in a check in dwarf_attr_list().

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2016-6131: gdb: libiberty emangler segfaults

long_desc.thetext:
+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #987552 +++
https://gcc.gnu.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=71696
Another vulnerability in GNU Libiberty was found that impacts the security of binary analysis tools, such as Valgrind, GDB, Binutils (e.g., objdump, nm, ..), Gcov, or other LibBFD-based tools. An attacker might modify a program binary such that it executes malicious code upon *analysis* of the binary (e.g., to find whether it is malicious in the first place) or during the attempt to reverse-engineer an untrusted binary.
Workaround: Until the patches propagate to the vulnerable tools, switch off default demangling! E.g., $ echo "set demangle-style none" >> ~/.gdbinit $ echo "--demangle=no" >> ~/.valgrindrc
A stackoverflow in the libiberty demangler causes its host application to crash on a tainted branch instruction. The problem is caused by a self-reference in a mangled type string that is "remembered" for later reference. This leads to an infinite recursion during the demangling. * GDB exploitable classifies the stack overflow as exploitable. * Bug Report: https://gcc.gnu.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=71696 * Patch under review: https://gcc.gnu.org/ml/gcc-patches/2016-06/msg02030.html
From patch submission:
The attached patch fixes the stack overflow in the demangler due to cycles in the references of “remembered” mangled types (https://gcc.gnu.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=71696).
The methods demangle_signature and do_arg in cplus-dem.c allow to “remember” mangled type names that can later be referenced and will also be demangled. The method demangle_args demangles those types following any references. So, if there is a cycle in the referencing (or in the simplest case a self-reference), the method enters infinite recursion.
The patch tracks the mangled types that are currently being demangled in a new variable called work->proctypevec. If a referenced type is currently being demangled, the demangling is marked as not successful.
Bootstrapped and regression tested on x86_64-pc-linux-gnu. Test case added to libiberty/testsuite/demangler-expected and checked PR71696 is resolved.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2016-6131 http://seclists.org/oss-sec/2016/q2/633 http://people.canonical.com/~ubuntu-security/cve/2016/CVE-2016-6131.html

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2016-4488: gcc: Invalid write due to a use-after-free to array ktypevec

long_desc.thetext:
rh#1333332 / CVE-2016-4488
A vulnerability was found in gcc. There is a variable ksize storing the amount of allocated memory for the array ktypevec. ksize being zero (0) indicates that some memory must be allocated upon the first write. When more memory is needed, both ksize and the memory are doubled during reallocation. At some point the memory for the array is freed (in squangle_mop_up) but the value of ksize remains. Since ksize is not 0, there is no indication that new memory must be allocated when there is another write to the array. This allows a malicious attacker to write arbitrary content to freed memory.
External references:
https://gcc.gnu.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=70481
Upstream fix:
https://gcc.gnu.org/ml/gcc-patches/2016-03/msg01687.html
References: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1333332 http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2016-4488 http://seclists.org/oss-sec/2016/q2/240
bugbot adjusting priority
Bug in symbol name de-mangling -> VUL-1.

The cited bug affects the libstdc++ demangler and thus libstdc++.so and libsupc++.a. The bug was fixed on the GCC 5 branch after the last update to the toolchain module and the fix will be included in the GCC 6 toolchain module release upcoming (and thus the system libstdc++.so).
Note that the copies in static libraries of older GCC do not get updated with the system runtime.
Note that bugs in the libstdc++ demangler are not as serious as those in the libiberty demangler which gets used by various tools such as gdb or nm.
Any update to GCC 5 should wait until after the GCC 6 toochain release to lessen the burden on QA (it no longer replaces the system runtime).

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2016-4487: gcc: Invalid write due to a use-after-free to array btypevec

long_desc.thetext:
rh#1333330 / CVE-2016-4487
A vulnerability was found in gcc. There is a variable bsize storing the amount of allocated memory for the array btypevec. bsize being zero (0) indicates that some memory must be allocated upon the first write. When more memory is needed, both bsize and the memory are doubled during reallocation. At some point the memory for the array is freed (in squangle_mop_up) but the value of bsize remains. Since bsize is not 0, there is no indication that new memory must be allocated when there is another write to the array. This results in NULL being written to the freed memory.
External references:
https://gcc.gnu.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=70481
Upstream fix:
https://gcc.gnu.org/ml/gcc-patches/2016-03/msg01687.html
References: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1333330 http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2016-4487 http://seclists.org/oss-sec/2016/q2/240

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2016-2226: gcc: Exploitable buffer overflow

long_desc.thetext:
rh#1333322 / CVE-2016-2226
A vulnerability was found in gcc. Specifically, it revolves around demangling while analysing the untrusted binaries. A particularly malicious attacker could craft an executable that executes when *analysed* by objdump, nm or gdb, or any other libbfd / libiberty - based forensics tool (if the demangling option is switched on).
External references:
https://gcc.gnu.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=69687
References:
http://seclists.org/oss-sec/2016/q2/238
Upstream fix:
https://gcc.gnu.org/viewcvs/gcc?view=revision&revision=234829
References: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1333322 http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2016-2226 http://seclists.org/oss-sec/2016/q2/240

POC for PR69687 ========================
** GDB and BINUTILS $ cat comileme.c #include <stdio.h> const char *__020A___________________X00020A___R0020A__U000R03000N99999999_020A__K000="Hello World"; int main() { printf("%s\n",__020A___________________X00020A___R0020A__U000R03000N99999999_020A__K000); } $ g++ compileme.c -o compileme $ ./compileme Hello World! $ gdb ./compileme .. $ objdump -x -C ./compileme .. $ nm -C ./compileme ..

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2018-8945: binutils: The bfd_section_from_shdr function in elf.c in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD)library (aka libbfd) allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2018-8945
The bfd_section_from_shdr function in elf.c in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.30, allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (segmentation fault) via a large attribute section.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2018-8945 http://people.canonical.com/~ubuntu-security/cve/2018/CVE-2018-8945.html http://www.cvedetails.com/cve/CVE-2018-8945/ https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=22809
Created attachment 764721 ELF reproducer
Created attachment 764722 PE reproducer
Created attachment 764723 Proposed upstream patch

Could not reproduce, upstream suggests that the memory allocation fails due to memory exhaustion. Attached patch should fix the big allocation.
attr support was added with commit 4b41ba5318, which first appeared in version 2.18. This makes the codestream "SUSE:SLE-10-SP3:Update" not affected. SLE11/SLE12 codestreams probably are and the patch should be applied.

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2018-20657: binutils: denial of service inside the demangle_template function in cplus-dem.c

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2018-20657
The demangle_template function in cplus-dem.c in GNU libiberty, as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.31.1, has a memory leak via a crafted string, leading to a denial of service (memory consumption), as demonstrated by cxxfilt, a related issue to CVE-2018-12698.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2018-20657 http://people.canonical.com/~ubuntu-security/cve/2018/CVE-2018-20657.html https://gcc.gnu.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=88539 http://www.securityfocus.com/bid/106444

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2018-1000876: binutils: integer overflow in bfd_get_dynamic_reloc_upper_bound,bfd_canonicalize_dynamic_reloc in objdump

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2018-1000876
binutils version 2.32 and earlier contains a Integer Overflow vulnerability in objdump, bfd_get_dynamic_reloc_upper_bound,bfd_canonicalize_dynamic_reloc that can result in Integer overflow trigger heap overflow. Successful exploitation allows execution of arbitrary code.. This attack appear to be exploitable via Local. This vulnerability appears to have been fixed in after commit 3a551c7a1b80fca579461774860574eabfd7f18f.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2018-1000876 http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2018-1000876 https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=23994 https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;h=3a551c7a1b80fca579461774860574eabfd7f18f http://www.securityfocus.com/bid/106304

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2018-10535: binutils: output_section pointer validation issue in ignore_section_sym function in elf.c

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2018-10535
The ignore_section_sym function in elf.c in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.30, does not validate the output_section pointer in the case of a symtab entry with a "SECTION" type that has a "0" value, which allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (NULL pointer dereference and application crash) via a crafted file, as demonstrated by objcopy.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2018-10535 https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=23113

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2018-10372: binutils: process_cu_tu_index allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (heap-based buffer over-read and application crash)

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2018-10372
process_cu_tu_index in dwarf.c in GNU Binutils 2.30 allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (heap-based buffer over-read and application crash) via a crafted binary file, as demonstrated by readelf.
Reproducer: readelf -w bug3 doesn't work without ASAN
All codestreams affected.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2018-10372 http://people.canonical.com/~ubuntu-security/cve/2018/CVE-2018-10372.html https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=23064

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2018-10373: binutils: concat_filename allows remote attackers to cause adenial of service (NULL pointer dereference)

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 768353 Reproducer
CVE-2018-10373
concat_filename in dwarf2.c in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.30, allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (NULL pointer dereference and application crash) via a crafted binary file, as demonstrated by nm-new.
Reproducer doesn't trigger without ASAN.
All codestreams affected.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2018-10373 http://people.canonical.com/~ubuntu-security/cve/2018/CVE-2018-10373.html https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=23065

bug.short_desc: VUL-0: CVE-2017-12448: binutils: bfd_cache_close function in bfd/cache.c allows remote attackers to cause a heap use after free and possibly achieve code execution

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2017-12448
The bfd_cache_close function in bfd/cache.c in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.29 and earlier, allows remote attackers to cause a heap use after free and possibly achieve code execution via a crafted nested archive file. This issue occurs because incorrect functions are called during an attempt to release memory. The issue can be addressed by better input validation in the bfd_generic_archive_p function in bfd/archive.c.
Upstream fix: https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;a=patch;h=909e4e716c4d77e33357bbe9bc902bfaf2e1af24
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2017-12448 http://people.canonical.com/~ubuntu-security/cve/2017/CVE-2017-12448.html https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=21787

Created attachment 735464 Reproducer
#> objdump -x use-after-free In archive test123: In nested archive : In nested archive : objdump: 0x2ffff00-0xffffff: File truncated objdump: 0x3c617220-0x20202020: File truncated objdump: 0x20600a3c-0x62696761: File truncated Segmentation fault (core dumped)

bug.short_desc: VUL-0: CVE-2017-12450: binutils: alpha_vms_object_p function in bfd/vms-alpha.c allows remote attackers to cause an out of bounds heap write and possibly achieve code execution

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2017-12450
The alpha_vms_object_p function in bfd/vms-alpha.c in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.29 and earlier, allows remote attackers to cause an out of bounds heap write and possibly achieve code execution via a crafted vms alpha file.
Upstream fix: https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;a=patch;h=ca4cf9b9c622a5695e01f7f5815a7382a31fcf51
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2017-12450 http://people.canonical.com/~ubuntu-security/cve/2017/CVE-2017-12450.html https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=21813

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2017-9955: binutils: DoS in get_build_id function in opncls.c

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2017-9955
The get_build_id function in opncls.c in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.28, allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (heap-based buffer over-read and application crash) via a crafted file in which a certain size field is larger than a corresponding data field, as demonstrated by mishandling within the objdump program.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2017-9955 http://www.cvedetails.com/cve/CVE-2017-9955/ https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=21665
Created attachment 730319 CVE-2017-9955.poc1
Created attachment 730320 CVE-2017-9955.poc2

I've was only able to run the reproducer on Tumbleweed. SLE didn't come up with any valgrind errors.
The second reproducer file didn't produce any error even on Tumbleweed.

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2017-8398: binutils: heap buffer overflow in printf_common (dwarf.c)

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 723334 21438_upstream_crash_info
Ref: https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2017-8398 =================================================== Description
dwarf.c in GNU Binutils 2.28 is vulnerable to an invalid read of size 1 during dumping of debug information from a corrupt binary. This vulnerability causes programs that conduct an analysis of binary programs, such as objdump and readelf, to crash. ===================================================
Hyperlink
[1] https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=21438
[2] https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;h=d949ff5607b9f595e0eed2ff15fbe5eb84eb3a34 (see https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=21438#c4)
(open-)SUSE: https://software.opensuse.org/package/binutils
2.28 (TW, official repo) 2.26.1 (42.{1,2}, official repo)
Created attachment 723335 21438_upstream_crash_info_add_1
Created attachment 723336 21438_upstream_crash_info_add_2
Created attachment 723337 21438_upstream_crash_info_add_3

QA REPRODUCER:
valgrind objdump -g bug_3
should not report
==14568== Invalid read of size 1 ==14568== at 0x5A3B829: vfprintf (vfprintf.c:1631) ==14568== by 0x5AE9B65: __printf_chk (printf_chk.c:35)

QA REPRODUCER for the readelf specific one:
valgrind readelf -w bug_9_To\ reproduce_\ readelf\ -w\ bug_9
should not show ==25205== Invalid read of size 1 ==25205== at 0x4E7E829: vfprintf (vfprintf.c:1631) ==25205== by 0x4F2CB65: __printf_chk (printf_chk.c:35)
I think in all versions SLE10 also looks affected.

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2017-7614: binutils: elflink.c in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd) NULL pointer undefined behavior could lead to denial of service

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2017-7614
elflink.c in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.28, has a "member access within null pointer" undefined behavior issue, which might allow remote attackers to cause a denial of service (application crash) or possibly have unspecified other impact via an "int main() {return 0;}" program.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2017-7614 http://www.cvedetails.com/cve/CVE-2017-7614/ http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2017-7614 https://blogs.gentoo.org/ago/2017/04/05/binutils-two-null-pointer-dereference-in-elflink-c/
note that it is not a NULL ptr deref, but a potential one under preconditions.

Yikes, that's a whole new class of pseudo-CVEs. This isn't even about fuzzing, but about using a undefined-behaviour checker (i.e. for checking of strict C language constraints) on some sources. In practice this specific type of undefined behaviour (an '&x->member' construct with x potentially NULL) is handled naturally by all compilers and poses no actual problem. This can't possibly trigger any segfault.
And of course let's all ignore the fact that elflink.c is only used by the linker and hence isn't exposed remotely (even less likely than something like readelf where it's already borderline if it even deserves CVEs).
The only reason why I don't close this a WONTFIX is because Nick was so nice to cobble up a patch already.

Of course the idea would be that bh would be dereferenced later.
_bfd_generic_link_add_one_symbol() in 2.28 catches bh being NULL (The if (*hashp==NULL)) checks.)
As much as I appreciate finding and fixing bugs, this one seems not have needed a CVE as there seems to be no impact.

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2017-16829: gdb: The _bfd_elf_parse_gnu_properties function in elf-properties.c doesn't prevent negative prointers and it could lead to remote denial of service

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2017-16829
The _bfd_elf_parse_gnu_properties function in elf-properties.c in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.29.1, does not prevent negative pointers, which allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (out-of-bounds read and application crash) or possibly have unspecified other impact via a crafted ELF file.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2017-16829 http://people.canonical.com/~ubuntu-security/cve/2017/CVE-2017-16829.html http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2017-16829 https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=22307 https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;h=cf54ebff3b7361989712fd9c0128a9b255578163
gdb uses the libbfd from binutils, which aren't affected.
gdb has it static linked but dont provide it. It is affected.

bug.short_desc: VUL-0: CVE-2017-16826: binutils: Invalid memory access on coff_slurp_line_table function in coffcode.h in libbfd could lead to denial of service

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2017-16826
The coff_slurp_line_table function in coffcode.h in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.29.1, allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (invalid memory access and application crash) or possibly have unspecified other impact via a crafted PE file.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2017-16826 http://people.canonical.com/~ubuntu-security/cve/2017/CVE-2017-16826.html http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2017-16826 https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;h=a67d66eb97e7613a38ffe6622d837303b3ecd31d https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=22376
likely exploitable
Please submit this for SUSE:SLE-10-SP3:Update SUSE:SLE-11-SP1:Update:Teradata SUSE:SLE-11-SP4:Update SUSE:SLE-12:Update Thank you
(In reply to Johannes Segitz from comment #2) ping, please submit

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2017-9750: binutils: DoS in opcodes/rx-decode.opc lacks bounds checks for certain scale arrays

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2017-9750
opcodes/rx-decode.opc in GNU Binutils 2.28 lacks bounds checks for certain scale arrays, which allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (buffer overflow and application crash) or possibly have unspecified other impact via a crafted binary file, as demonstrated by mishandling of this file during "objdump -D" execution.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2017-9750 http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2017-9750 https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=21587

Reproducer from https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=21587 did not work on SLE or openSUSE.
#> objdump -D testcase.cve-2017-9750
testcase.cve-2017-9750: file format elf32-little
objdump: can't disassemble for architecture UNKNOWN!
However, the affected/fixed code is present.
Upstream Fix: https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;h=db5fa770268baf8cc82cf9b141d69799fd485fe2
Low prio, but yeah, we enable this architecture.

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2017-9748: binutils: DoS in ieee_object_p function in bfd/ieee.c

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2017-9748
The ieee_object_p function in bfd/ieee.c in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.28, might allow remote attackers to cause a denial of service (buffer overflow and application crash) or possibly have unspecified other impact via a crafted binary file, as demonstrated by mishandling of this file during "objdump -D" execution. NOTE: this may be related to a compiler bug.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2017-9748 http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2017-9748 https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=21582

Reproducer from https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=21582 is not working in SLE or openSUSE.
#> objdump -D testcase.cve-2017-9748 objdump: testcase.cve-2017-9748: File truncated
However, the affected/fixed code is present.
Upstream Fix: https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;h=63634bb4a107877dd08b6282e28e11cfd1a1649e
Low prio typical fuzzing "CVE" from script kiddies.

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2017-8394: binutils: libbfd: Segfault in objcopy (_bfd_elf_large_com_section)

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 723326 21414_upstream_crash_info
Ref: https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2017-8394 ==================================================== Description
The Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.28, is vulnerable to an invalid read of size 4 due to NULL pointer dereferencing of _bfd_elf_large_com_section. This vulnerability causes programs that conduct an analysis of binary programs using the libbfd library, such as objcopy, to crash. ====================================================

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2018-20623: binutils: use-after-free in the error function in elfcomm.c

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2018-20623
In GNU Binutils 2.31.1, there is a use-after-free in the error function in elfcomm.c when called from the process_archive function in readelf.c via a crafted ELF file.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2018-20623 http://people.canonical.com/~ubuntu-security/cve/2018/CVE-2018-20623.html http://www.securityfocus.com/bid/106370 https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=24049

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2018-20651: binutils: denial of service via a NULL pointer dereference in elf_link_add_object_symbols in elflink.c

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2018-20651
A NULL pointer dereference was discovered in elf_link_add_object_symbols in elflink.c in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.31.1. This occurs for a crafted ET_DYN with no program headers. A specially crafted ELF file allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service, as demonstrated by ld.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2018-20651 http://people.canonical.com/~ubuntu-security/cve/2018/CVE-2018-20651.html https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=24041 https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;h=54025d5812ff100f5f0654eb7e1ffd50f2e37f5f http://www.securityfocus.com/bid/106440

Right, as demonstrated by ld remote attackers can cause a denial of service. Of course.
The is lower than none priority, but bugzilla doesn't have that.

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2018-19931: binutils: heap-based buffer overflow in bfd_elf32_swap_phdr_in in elfcode.h

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2018-19931
An issue was discovered in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils through 2.31. There is a heap-based buffer overflow in bfd_elf32_swap_phdr_in in elfcode.h because the number of program headers is not restricted.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2018-19931 http://people.canonical.com/~ubuntu-security/cve/2018/CVE-2018-19931.html http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2018-19931
https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=23942 https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;h=5f60af5d24d181371d67534fa273dd221df20c07

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2018-17985: binutils: stack consumption problem caused by the cplus_demangle_type

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2018-17985
An issue was discovered in cp-demangle.c in GNU libiberty, as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.31. There is a stack consumption problem caused by the cplus_demangle_type function making recursive calls to itself in certain scenarios involving many 'P' characters.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2018-17985 http://people.canonical.com/~ubuntu-security/cve/2018/CVE-2018-17985.html http://www.cvedetails.com/cve/CVE-2018-17985/ https://gcc.gnu.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=87335
reproducer does not work and upstream does not seem convinced it is an issue. Monitoring upstream to see if there is any progress.
upstream fix now available: https://gcc.gnu.org/viewcvs/gcc?view=revision&revision=266886

Created attachment 796601 QA Reproducer
$ ulimit -s 2048 && c++filt -t < POC-t Segmentation fault (core dumped)

Assume these codestreams as affected: - SUSE:SLE-11-SP1:Update:Teradata - SUSE:SLE-11-SP3:Update - SUSE:SLE-11-SP4:Update - SUSE:SLE-12:Update - SUSE:SLE-15:Update
Not affected because the code seems to be missing: - SUSE:SLE-10-SP3:Update

We've got a question from a customer why our CVSSv3 score has AV:N (attack vector network), while NIST NVD has AV:L (local); Strangely, the NVD CVSSv2 also has AV:N. I think AV:L is correct, how can this be exploited remotely?

(In reply to Joerg Reuter from comment #14) > We've got a question from a customer why our CVSSv3 score has AV:N (attack > vector network), while NIST NVD has AV:L (local); Strangely, the NVD CVSSv2 > also has AV:N. I think AV:L is correct, how can this be exploited remotely?
I don't see how it can be exploited remotely unless you go long ways like causing a crash in a remotely accessible program plus somehow arranging that a symbol in the backtrace of that crash involves a malicious symbol (by somehow overwriting the symbol table), have systemd-coredump running and core dumps enabled and systemd-coredump doing the backtrace which I believe demangles symbols (now you have to research which copy of the demangler systemd uses here - I think it one from elfutils which probably uses libiberty as well).
So yeah, AV:L (local) looks correct here.
And of course systemd inspecting random coredumps is a security issue ;) Hopefully it does this in fully isolated sandboxes. Heh.

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2018-18605: binutils: A heap-based buffer over-read issue was discovered in the function sec_merge_hash_lookup causing a denial of service

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2018-18605 A heap-based buffer over-read issue was discovered in the function sec_merge_hash_lookup in merge.c in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.31, because _bfd_add_merge_section mishandles section merges when size is not a multiple of entsize. A specially crafted ELF allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service, as demonstrated by ld.
upstream patch: https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;a=commitdiff;h=ab419ddbb2cdd17ca83618990f2cacf904ce1d61;hp=8e3152af14a91df65af8e922a0e8e77c60ed99ba
upstream ticket: https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=23804
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2018-18605 http://people.canonical.com/~ubuntu-security/cve/2018/CVE-2018-18605.html

Hi Michael, again the provided patch suggests that all codestreams are affected: - SUSE:SLE-15:Update/binutils - SUSE:SLE-12:Update/binutils - SUSE:SLE-11-SP4:Update/binutils - SUSE:SLE-11-SP3:Update/binutils - SUSE:SLE-11-SP1:Update:Teradata/binutils - SUSE:SLE-10-SP3:Update/binutils

Created attachment 787127 QA reproducer (2)
$ ld -E POC2 segfaults, again verified in a openSUSE Leap 15.0 container

Created attachment 787128 QA reproducer (1)
$ ld -E POC1
reproducer segfaults, verified in openSUSE Leap 15.0 container

Why is this a security bug? It's a problem in the link editor with invalid input, how do you propose this to become relevant from a security p.o.v.? I.e. it's even less relevant than random bugs in binutils that can be observed by calling nm or similar tools for forensic analysis.
Hence, I'm not going to backport anything for this.

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2018-18606: binutils: NULL pointer dereference in _bfd_add_merge_section when attempting to merge sections with large alignments, causing denial of service

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2018-18606 An issue was discovered in the merge_strings function in merge.c in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.31. There is a NULL pointer dereference in _bfd_add_merge_section when attempting to merge sections with large alignments. A specially crafted ELF allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service, as demonstrated by ld.
upstream patch: https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;a=commitdiff;h=45a0eaf77022963d639d6d19871dbab7b79703fc;hp=102def4da826b3d9e169741421e5e67e8731909a
upstream ticket: https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=23806
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2018-18606 http://people.canonical.com/~ubuntu-security/cve/2018/CVE-2018-18606.html

Hi Michael, reviewing the provided patch suggests again that all codestreams are affected: - SUSE:SLE-15:Update/binutils - SUSE:SLE-12:Update/binutils - SUSE:SLE-11-SP4:Update/binutils - SUSE:SLE-11-SP3:Update/binutils - SUSE:SLE-11-SP1:Update:Teradata/binutils - SUSE:SLE-10-SP3:Update/binutils

Created attachment 787124 QA reproducer
$ ld -E POC_ldSEGV2
reproducer segfaults, verified in openSUSE Leap 15.0 container

Why is this a security bug? It's a problem in the link editor with invalid input, how do you propose this to become relevant from a security p.o.v.? I.e. it's even less relevant than random bugs in binutils that can be observed by calling nm or similar tools for forensic analysis.
Hence, I'm not going to backport anything for this.

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2018-18607: binutils: NULL pointer dereference in elf_link_input_bfd when used for finding STT_TLS symbols without any TLS section, causing denial of service

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2018-18607 An issue was discovered in elf_link_input_bfd in elflink.c in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.31. There is a NULL pointer dereference in elf_link_input_bfd when used for finding STT_TLS symbols without any TLS section. A specially crafted ELF allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service, as demonstrated by ld.
upstream patch: https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;a=commitdiff;h=102def4da826b3d9e169741421e5e67e8731909a;hp=ab419ddbb2cdd17ca83618990f2cacf904ce1d61
upstream ticket: https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=23805
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2018-18607 http://people.canonical.com/~ubuntu-security/cve/2018/CVE-2018-18607.html

Created attachment 787123 QA reproducer
$ ld -E POC_ldSEGV1
Segfaults, verified in openSUSE Leap 15.0 container

Hi Michael, reviewing the code and the provided patch my understanding is that all codestreams are affected: - SUSE:SLE-15:Update/binutils - SUSE:SLE-12:Update/binutils - SUSE:SLE-11-SP4:Update/binutils - SUSE:SLE-11-SP3:Update/binutils - SUSE:SLE-11-SP1:Update:Teradata/binutils - SUSE:SLE-10-SP3:Update/binutils

Why is this a security bug? It's a problem in the link editor with invalid input, how do you propose this to become relevant from a security p.o.v.? I.e. it's even less relevant than random bugs in binutils that can be observed by calling nm or similar tools for forensic analysis.
Hence, I'm not going to backport anything for this.

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2018-18309: binutils: An invalid memory address dereference was discovered in read_reloc in reloc.c

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2018-18309: An issue was discovered in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.31. An invalid memory address dereference was discovered in read_reloc in reloc.c. The vulnerability causes a segmentation fault and application crash, which leads to denial of service, as demonstrated by objdump, because of missing _bfd_clear_contents bounds checking.
upstream fix: https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;a=patch;h=0930cb3021b8078b34cf216e79eb8608d017864f;hp=2bf2bf23da5237f465fdbb759657aeb7825a08a3
upstream ticket: https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=23770
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2018-18309 http://people.canonical.com/~ubuntu-security/cve/2018/CVE-2018-18309.html

Hi Michael, my investigation suggests the following about the different codestreams.
affected: - SUSE:SLE-15:Update/binutils - SUSE:SLE-12:Update/binutils
probably affected, but code differs: - SUSE:SLE-11-SP4:Update/binutils - SUSE:SLE-11-SP3:Update/binutils - SUSE:SLE-11-SP1:Update:Teradata/binutils
probably _not_ affected, but wanted to confirm - SUSE:SLE-10-SP3:Update/binutils

Created attachment 786141 QA reproducer
$ objdump -xg -W POC_SEGV (could not reproduce the issue in my setup)

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2018-17360: binutils: heap-based buffer over-read in bfd_getl32 in libbfd.c

long_desc.thetext:
CVE-2018-17360
An issue was discovered in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.31. a heap-based buffer over-read in bfd_getl32 in libbfd.c allows an attacker to cause a denial of service through a crafted PE file. This vulnerability can be triggered by the executable objdump.
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2018-17360 https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=23685

bug.short_desc: VUL-1: CVE-2018-6323: binutils: The elf_object_p function in elfcode.h in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd) has an unsigned integer overflow because bfd_size_type multiplication is not used

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 757724 Reproducer
CVE-2018-6323
The elf_object_p function in elfcode.h in the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd), as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.29.1, has an unsigned integer overflow because bfd_size_type multiplication is not used. A crafted ELF file allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (application crash) or possibly have unspecified other impact.
This problem only affects i686.
Reproducer (does not trigger on x86_64): objdump -x c2
Upstream fix: https://sourceware.org/git/gitweb.cgi?p=binutils-gdb.git;h=38e64b0ecc7f4ee64a02514b8d532782ac057fa2
References: http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2018-6323 https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=22746
