bug.short_desc: gdb does not build reproducibly

long_desc.thetext:
most content in /usr/share/doc/packages/gdb-testresults differs for every build. I guess it should be split into a separate build like with gcc8-testresults or using the (still ugly) _multibuild feature in OBS, like glibc
Another approach could be to not package the testresults at all and just print them into the build log or into another side artifact.

Can you explain "other side artifact"? Is that a new OBS feature we can use to make the testresults accessible?
IMHO we want the ability to mark a sub-package "volatile" as to not trigger rebuilds of packages depending on it -- but nothing should depend on gdb-testresults so why exactly is that not reproducing an issue at all?

https://build.opensuse.org/package/binaries/openSUSE:Factory/gdb/standard already has '_buildenv' and 'rpmlint.log' as side-artifacts for download which do not influence pkg-diff calculation.
Not sure, if/how it is possible to make these in a build.
A "volatile" flag for subpackages could also help, because I think, currently all of gdb always gets republished and there are packages that BuildRequire gdb, which could create cycles.
> grep '^BuildRequires.*gdb$' */*.spec|cut -d/ -f1 |sort -u 389-ds cimple coreutils coreutils-testsuite crda cross-*-gcc7 gcc7 gcc7-testresults gcc8 glibc go1.* installation-images ldc libqt5-creator nemiver python-qt5 verilator

(In reply to Bernhard Wiedemann from comment #2) > https://build.opensuse.org/package/binaries/openSUSE:Factory/gdb/standard > already has '_buildenv' and 'rpmlint.log' as side-artifacts for download > which do not influence pkg-diff calculation. > > Not sure, if/how it is possible to make these in a build.
And make them "nicely" downloadable from the UI. Maybe we generally can add a _testresults "stream" a package build could store a tar archieve to for example?
> A "volatile" flag for subpackages could also help, > because I think, currently all of gdb always gets republished > and there are packages that BuildRequire gdb, which could create cycles. > > > grep '^BuildRequires.*gdb$' */*.spec|cut -d/ -f1 |sort -u > 389-ds > cimple > coreutils > coreutils-testsuite > crda > cross-*-gcc7 > gcc7 > gcc7-testresults > gcc8 > glibc > go1.* > installation-images > ldc > libqt5-creator > nemiver > python-qt5 > verilator
Awww, so re-building gets decided on whether _any_ of the sub-packages of the source package of a dependency changed? Ugh...
So a "volatile" package should then not being depend on.

bug.short_desc: ltrace shows no parameters when debuginfo installed

long_desc.thetext:
$ ltrace echo __libc_start_main([ "echo" ] <unfinished ...> getenv("POSIXLY_CORRECT") = nil strrchr("echo", '/') = nil setlocale(LC_ALL, "") = "cs_CZ.UTF-8" bindtextdomain("coreutils", "/usr/share/locale") = "/usr/share/locale" textdomain("coreutils") = "coreutils" ...
# zypper in coreutils-debuginfo
$ ltrace echo __libc_start_main([ "echo" ] <unfinished ...> getenv() = <void> strrchr() = <void> setlocale() = <void> bindtextdomain() = <void> textdomain() = <void> ...
Seems like ltrace DW support is broken somehow.

Created attachment 693723 potential fix
This fixes it for me. It really makes no sense to import functions from dwarf which have no prototype in there.
The only problem I see with the patch is that dwarf specs says "may have": "A subroutine entry declared with a function prototype style declaration may have a DW_AT_prototyped attribute, which is a flag."
Why does the debug info have no prototypes? That looks like a bug in the compiler output.

(In reply to Michael Matz from comment #3) > Jiri: can you look at coreutils-debuginfo if it contains getenv entries? > (Use readelf -wi for inspection).
Yes, it does. I checked it before, that's why the patch works :).
<1><1414>: Abbrev Number: 65 (DW_TAG_subprogram) <1415> DW_AT_external : 1 <1415> DW_AT_declaration : 1 <1415> DW_AT_linkage_name: (indirect string, offset: 0x48b): getenv <1419> DW_AT_name : (indirect string, offset: 0x48b): getenv <141d> DW_AT_decl_file : 23 <141e> DW_AT_decl_line : 564
DW_AT_decl_file 23 is /usr/include/stdlib.h: 559-#endif 560- 561- 562-__BEGIN_NAMESPACE_STD 563-/* Return the value of envariable NAME, or NULL if it doesn't exist. */ 564:extern char *getenv (const char *__name) __THROW __nonnull ((1)) __wur; 565-__END_NAMESPACE_STD 566- 567-#ifdef __USE_GNU 568-/* This function is similar to the above but returns NULL if the

Hmpf. I wonder how that came into the debuginfo. As shown above a simple testcase merely calling getenv doesn't do that.
OTOH that's a side issue. It may or may not be regarded as quality of implementation issue of GCC to produce such debug entry, but it's certainly valid to do so (e.g. one could be interested in sort of minimal debug info that has top-level entities but nothing further, also no formal arguments; that is for instance what -g1 is doing actually). Ideally ltrace would work with both debug infos, so I think making it more accepting seems sensible.
I checked some GCC versions and they relieably seem to add the DW_AT_prototyped flag whenever the entity also has formal parameter children; so testing for that flag should be enough for ignoring those entries for ltrace purposes.
In 13.2 or 42.1 the debuginfo contains fully prototyped entries. Why is factory different?

(In reply to Andreas Schwab from comment #6) > In 13.2 or 42.1 the debuginfo contains fully prototyped entries. Why is > factory different?
I guess gcc-6 makes the difference in that case. If somebody provides us a preprocessed file I can analyze this.

(In reply to Michael Matz from comment #7) > (In reply to Andreas Schwab from comment #6) > > In 13.2 or 42.1 the debuginfo contains fully prototyped entries. Why is > > factory different? > > I guess gcc-6 makes the difference in that case. If somebody provides us a > preprocessed file I can analyze this.
I tried your example from comment #3. I need -O2 to have getenv in dw. gcc-5 behaves the same.
42.2 have debuginfo with prototypes too.
OTOH, gcc-6 on 42.2 does not put getenv into dw.

(In reply to Jiri Slaby from comment #9) > OTOH, gcc-6 on 42.2 does not put getenv into dw.
Wrong: gcc-6 on 42.2 DOES put getenv into dw, but without prototype: $ gcc-6 dw.c -o dw.o -g -c -O2 && readelf -wi dw.o|grep -C 5 getenv <359> DW_AT_abstract_origin: <0x36a> <2><35d>: Abbrev Number: 0 <1><35e>: Abbrev Number: 22 (DW_TAG_subprogram) <35f> DW_AT_external : 1 <35f> DW_AT_declaration : 1 <35f> DW_AT_linkage_name: (indirect string, offset: 0x186): getenv <363> DW_AT_name : (indirect string, offset: 0x186): getenv <367> DW_AT_decl_file : 7 <368> DW_AT_decl_line : 564 <1><36a>: Abbrev Number: 23 (DW_TAG_subprogram) <36b> DW_AT_external : 1 <36b> DW_AT_declaration : 1
gcc 4.8 puts in the prototype: gcc-4.8 dw.c -o dw.o -g -c -O2 && readelf -wi dw.o|grep -C 5 getenv <2fb> DW_AT_type : <0x264> <2ff> DW_AT_external : 1 <2ff> DW_AT_declaration : 1 <1><2ff>: Abbrev Number: 19 (DW_TAG_subprogram) <300> DW_AT_external : 1 <300> DW_AT_name : (indirect string, offset: 0x268): getenv <304> DW_AT_decl_file : 6 <305> DW_AT_decl_line : 564 <307> DW_AT_prototyped : 1 <307> DW_AT_type : <0x8b> <30b> DW_AT_declaration : 1

For completeness, gcc 5 on factory: $ gcc-5 dw.c -o dw.o -g -c -O2 && readelf -wi dw.o|grep -C 5 getenv <2f1> DW_AT_external : 1 <2f1> DW_AT_declaration : 1 <1><2f1>: Abbrev Number: 18 (DW_TAG_subprogram) <2f2> DW_AT_external : 1 <2f2> DW_AT_declaration : 1 <2f2> DW_AT_linkage_name: (indirect string, offset: 0x28a): getenv <2f6> DW_AT_name : (indirect string, offset: 0x28a): getenv <2fa> DW_AT_decl_file : 6 <2fb> DW_AT_decl_line : 564 <1><2fd>: Abbrev Number: 19 (DW_TAG_subprogram) <2fe> DW_AT_external : 1 <2fe> DW_AT_declaration : 1

And to fill the gap, 4.9 is still OK: $ gcc-4.9 dw.c -o dw.o -g -c -O2 && readelf -wi dw.o|grep -C 5 getenv <2fb> DW_AT_type : <0x264> <2ff> DW_AT_external : 1 <2ff> DW_AT_declaration : 1 <1><2ff>: Abbrev Number: 19 (DW_TAG_subprogram) <300> DW_AT_external : 1 <300> DW_AT_name : (indirect string, offset: 0x268): getenv <304> DW_AT_decl_file : 6 <305> DW_AT_decl_line : 564 <307> DW_AT_prototyped : 1 <307> DW_AT_type : <0x8b> <30b> DW_AT_declaration : 1
So it has to be something new in gcc-5.

Created attachment 694994 preprocessed file
(In reply to Michael Matz from comment #7) > I guess gcc-6 makes the difference in that case. If somebody provides us a > preprocessed file I can analyze this.
Attached.

(In reply to Jiri Slaby from comment #8) > (In reply to Michael Matz from comment #7) > > (In reply to Andreas Schwab from comment #6) > > > In 13.2 or 42.1 the debuginfo contains fully prototyped entries. Why is > > > factory different? > > > > I guess gcc-6 makes the difference in that case. If somebody provides us a > > preprocessed file I can analyze this. > > I tried your example from comment #3. I need -O2 to have getenv in dw. gcc-5 > behaves the same.
Oh wow. It never occured to me to try -g -O2 as producing more debug info (even if incomplete) than just -g. Okay I can reproduce, will poke at this a bit. Thanks.

It's a "feature" to implement DW_TAG_GNU_call_site / DW_TAG_GNU_call_site_parameter support. You get this non-prototyped decl also with -O0 if you enable -fvar-tracking. The non-prototyped form is the minimal info that is needed it seems.
It seems to be fixed somehow.

(In reply to Jiri Slaby from comment #1) > Created attachment 693723 [details] > potential fix
Reopening as this patch is still needed. No matter whether glibc-debuginfo is installed or not, it behaves the same. Important is how the code below is compiled (-g -Og needed).
Source: #include <stdio.h>
int main(void) { fwrite("a", 1, 1, stdout); fwrite("b", 1, 1, stdout); fwrite("\n", 1, 1, stdout);
return 0; }
Build: gcc tracer.c -Og -g
Without the patch: $ ltrace ./a.out fwrite() = <void> fwrite() = <void> fwrite(ab ) = <void> +++ exited (status 0) +++
With the patch: ltrace ./a.out fwrite("a", 1, 1, 0x7f049ee5b760) = 1 fwrite("b", 1, 1, 0x7f049ee5b760) = 1 fwrite("\n", 1, 1, 0x7f049ee5b760ab ) = 1 +++ exited (status 0) +++
I tried to build with all these flags, but the issue is not reproducible, so Og must enable some more: -fcombine-stack-adjustments -fcompare-elim -fcprop-registers -fdefer-pop -fforward-propagate -fguess-branch-probability -fipa-profile -fipa-pure-const -fipa-reference -fomit-frame-pointer -freorder-blocks -fshrink-wrap -fsplit-wide-types -ftree-builtin-call-dce -ftree-ccp -ftree-coalesce-vars -ftree-copy-prop -ftree-dce -ftree-dominator-opts -ftree-dse -ftree-fre -ftree-ch -ftree-sink -ftree-slsr -ftree-ter

bug.short_desc: -fstack-clash-protection writes beyond array bounds

long_desc.thetext:
When allocating a zero-length array with alloca or as a VLA the code produced by -fstack-clash-protection accesses the array beyond bounds. The failure can best be seen on armv7 (or targets without their own probe_stack insn) where a stack probe is destructive, and where it breaks glibc.
https://build.opensuse.org/package/live_build_log/Base:System/glibc/openSUSE_Factory_ARM/armv7l
The C standard says that VLA shall not have zero size, but a size of 1 is valid, and the default probe_stack expansion writes to a MEM of word_mode.

So we have to surround the code generated by the final
+ if (flag_stack_clash_protection) + emit_stack_probe (target);
with a compare against zero and jump.
SLE is affected as well.

(In reply to Andreas Schwab from comment #1) > The C standard says that VLA shall not have zero size, but a size of 1 is > valid, and the default probe_stack expansion writes to a MEM of word_mode.
So the question is whether we at least align the allocation to word_mode which I doubt.
GCC supports zero length arrays, but it is unclear if it also supports zero length VLA.
ldconfig on aarch64 is also affected.
Hmpf. Indeed, some hardening is in order, aligning the size to wordmode and checking for zeroness. I'm going to work on that, but the labs conf interferes a small bit.

The generated code for probing "char zero[pad]":
mov r6, sp add r3, r3, #7 bic r3, r3, #7 cmp r3, #4096 bcc .L128 .L186: sub r3, r3, #4096 sub sp, sp, #4096 cmp r3, #4096 str r0, [sp, #8] bcs .L186 .L128: ldr r7, [fp, #-56] sub sp, sp, r3 mov r1, #0 add r3, sp, #8 mov r0, r3 str r0, [sp, #8]
The offset of #8 means that it overwrites a nearby variable.

For "char *dir = strdupa (aux_cache_name);" it generates an insn with unpredictable behavior:
mov r0, r5 bl strlen(PLT) add r3, r0, #15 add r2, r0, #1 bic r3, r3, #7 cmp r3, #4096 bcc .L281 .L320: sub r3, r3, #4096 sub sp, sp, #4096 cmp r3, #4096 str r0, [sp] bcs .L320 .L281: sub sp, sp, r3 ldr r1, [fp, #-172] mov r0, sp str r0, [r0], #7 <====== bic r0, r0, #7 bl memcpy(PLT)
cache.s:2116: Warning: source register same as write-back base
The latter is filed as PR82248.
so both arm 32 and 64bit are currently broken regardng that option?
It is unknown whether other architectures are affected.

As one data point: I was comparing the testresults (GCC testsuite) of all SLE11 architectures on gcc43 with this patch, they were clean. So either the testsuite doesn't contain a problematic alloca, or only aarch64 is affected. Are we caring for arm 32 bit?
Most likely none of them is testing zero-size VLA.
My home:matz2:clash-check project made enough progress on armv7l and aarch64 that I think I've fixed the problem, so gcc7 is submitted as SR #528941 now.
Is this now better?
Looks so.

bug.short_desc: Application stalls in Unwind function

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 743560 HANA profile
When throwing multiple exceptions (50++) in parallel, our HANA development observes that HANA can become extremely slow or completely hangs for a longer time on very large systems (UV300 / 32 sockets / 48 TiB). Their analysis shows that most of the time (90%) is spent in the Unwind function, as can be seen in the attached profile.
They currently try to mitigate the problem by avoiding exceptions as much as possible, but since the problem is still there and can heavily impact productive usage, they would like to understand the situation better.
When searching the web for similar issues, we came across this thread https://lists.freebsd.org/pipermail/freebsd-threads/2008-April/004262.html
with the related (invalid) bug entry https://gcc.gnu.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=36030
Although invalid at that time, the bug more or less describes our current problem. Is there something where we could jointly follow up on? The system is running a recent SLE 12 SP1 and our colleagues suspect the situation to be impacted by larger environments.
Than you very much in advance!

I think the __dl_iterate_phdr bottleneck is known (can't find a glibc bugzilla tho). Given in your case we have many readers and no writers so a multi-reader/single-writer lock would be a convenient thing to have there. I've not seen such in glibcs infrastructure tho.
CCing glibc folks.
There's pthread_rwlock_* at least, so that's sth that could be used. Of course needs to move somewhere accessible from non-threaded glibc parts.
C++ exceptions are designed to be the exception, not the rule, thus are optimized for not being taken.

See https://gcc.gnu.org/ml/gcc/2013-05/msg00253.html for a lengthy discussion about lock contention and many calls to dl_iterate_phdr.
Due to the nature of unwinding together with dlopen/dlclose facilities we can't get rid of the locks itself. The about only ideas in that mail thread are revolving around thread-local or per-unwind-local caching of information and I personally don't see any other possibilities either. Those ideas are more or less theoretic, most have deep ABI implications.
Regarding mostly-read structures (comment #1): since glibc 2.12 (i.e. long before SLE-12) dl_iterate_phdr uses a write-specific lock:
int __dl_iterate_phdr (int (*callback) (struct dl_phdr_info *info, size_t size, void *data), void *data) { struct link_map *l; struct dl_phdr_info info; int ret = 0;
/* Make sure nobody modifies the list of loaded objects. */ __rtld_lock_lock_recursive (GL(dl_load_write_lock)); __libc_cleanup_push (cancel_handler, NULL); ...
But even though this lock is specific for the write path (i.e. the dlopen/close routines take it only before modifying any of the interesting data structures), the above call simply uses __rtld_lock_lock_recursive, which, if I'm understanding the various glibc internal headers correctly, doesn't make a difference between readers and writers.
If so, then the above locking call synchronizes also between different callers of dl_iterate_phdr, without any need to do so, as this function only reads.
So, yes, this specific instance of overly blocky dl_iterate_phdr might be solvable by using proper read/write locks. Andreas, any opinion?
Libc locks are simple (recursive) mutexes, if you need finer graned locking you need to use separate locks.
There is also __libc_rwlock_t, but it lacks infrastructure to be usable from rtld.
Ah, yes, I see. Using it for the dl_load_write_lock would most probably help this specific use case quite some. Would be cool to work on getting the infrastructure in place for this.

Replacing just dl_load_write_lock with a rwlock won't help because that lock is only held when the list of loaded objects is about to be modified. This is already the minimum required extent where __dl_iterate_phdr needs to be locked out.

(In reply to Andreas Schwab from comment #10) > Replacing just dl_load_write_lock with a rwlock won't help because that lock > is only held when the list of loaded objects is about to be modified. This > is already the minimum required extent where __dl_iterate_phdr needs to be > locked out.
It will help removing the lock contention on simultaneous invocations of __dl_iterate_phdr because that function only needs to take a read lock.

Just for completeness let me also mention these bugreports discussing this and related problems: https://gcc.gnu.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=71744 (Concurrently throwing exceptions is not scalable, but not testcase just general discussion) and https://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=2377 which contains a testcase involving exceptions, threads and dlopen/close (the latter being the reason for the locks).

Sorry for the flurry of comments :) From the above glibc thread which contains the testcase the author tried a hack with an rwlock and didn't see performance improvements with it (on the testcase), as also rwlocks seem to hold a lock (and not using atomics?), for a short time, but still a synchronization point.
In any case, we should try nevertheless and make SAP try that then.
I don't think dl_iterate_phdr can usefully be made to run in parallel without fixing the cache usage in the libgcc unwinder.
Hmm, possibly. So we need a patch for libgcc as well which makes its cache either unused or thread local. The patch is simple enough, SAP: which gcc/libgcc version are you currently using?

(In reply to Michael Matz from comment #16) > Hmm, possibly. So we need a patch for libgcc as well which makes its cache > either unused or thread local. The patch is simple enough, SAP: which > gcc/libgcc version are you currently using?
Thank you Michael (and of course Andreas and Richard), this discussion already looks very promising! We are going to check what HANA version was used in the specific customer case, as the gcc/libgcc version depends on the version used, and our colleagues are trying to prepare a comparable test system. Since we are using the toolchain module, shouldn't the newest libgcc_s1-package be sufficient?

(In reply to Michael Matz from comment #16) > Hmm, possibly. So we need a patch for libgcc as well which makes its cache > either unused or thread local. The patch is simple enough, SAP: which > gcc/libgcc version are you currently using?
So the cache relies on an implementation detail (we never get concurrent invocations of the _Unwind_IteratePhdrCallback due to the lock in the glibc implementation). Sth that seems worth to fix anyway for correctness, like by making it thread-local or by making cache operations atomic or wrapped inside a lock (eh...). I guess the cache might not work very well with threads anyhow.
L3:49392 is now handled by Vasilis Liaskovitis.

Severity and priority are not set correctly. It's a very complicated issue and it's very old and known since a long time and occurs only when using exceptions in an arguably wrong way. It can't be major, and certainly is not of high priority. In fact there's actually no bug. It's a feature request really.

(In reply to Michael Matz from comment #20) > Severity and priority are not set correctly. It's a very complicated issue > and it's very old and known since a long time and occurs only when using > exceptions in an arguably wrong way. It can't be major, and certainly is > not of high priority. In fact there's actually no bug. It's a feature > request really.
OK, it seems this could be handled as a FATE then, and is outside of L3 scope. I marked this as enhancement and medium priority, but feel free to change. I will close the L3 if there are no objections.

(In reply to Vasilis Liaskovitis from comment #21) > (In reply to Michael Matz from comment #20) > > OK, it seems this could be handled as a FATE then, and is outside of L3 > scope. I marked this as enhancement and medium priority, but feel free to > change. I will close the L3 if there are no objections.
It could be handled as L3-question as well, I believe. The thing is, eventually we might want to give SAP some TEST packages for them to try, which are normally built by L3; it just isn't very urgent. Would that work for you to leave L3 involved in this one?

(In reply to Michael Matz from comment #22) > It could be handled as L3-question as well, I believe. The thing is, > eventually we might want to give SAP some TEST packages for them to try, > which are normally built by L3; it just isn't very urgent. Would that work > for you to leave L3 involved in this one?
Sure that works, I can leave L3 open.
If you think it will take a long time (e.g. more than 4-6 weeks) to prepare TEST packages, as it is not urgent, I can also close and re-open L3 when you have the packages for them to try.
@Michael I am assigning this to you. Feel free to re-assign though.
@Michael, let me know if there is a candidate patch to be tested here - I can then build an L3 for the partner to test.

(In reply to Vasilis Liaskovitis from comment #25) > @Michael, let me know if there is a candidate patch to be tested here - I > can then build an L3 for the partner to test.
I will, but I doubt it'll happen this year.

@Michael, any chance to get a test package in the next weeks?
If a patch is not likely to happen in Q1, I 'll close the L3 and re-open it once you have a patch for testing. The bug can stay open of course.

(In reply to Vasilis Liaskovitis from comment #27) > @Michael, any chance to get a test package in the next weeks?
Pfew, I don't know. Let's be realistic and say no.
> If a patch is not likely to happen in Q1, I 'll close the L3 and re-open it > once you have a patch for testing. The bug can stay open of course.
Okay, then let's do that.

bug.short_desc: gdb not linked with libipt

long_desc.thetext:
gdb 7.11 is not linked with libipt, which means reverse debugging and tracing with Processor Trace on newer Intel CPUs does not work
For this libipt would need to be packaged
https://github.com/01org/processor-trace/commits/master
and the gdb configure line should use --with-intel-pt=yes

Any updates here?
PT backwards debugging still doesn't work in the opensuse gdb because of this.
Sorry, this fell through the cracks. I'll include it in the next update.

bug.short_desc: binutils: enable as-needed by default

long_desc.thetext:
Inside the build service environment created by /usr/bin/build, $SUSE_ASNEEDED is set and ld behaves as if it were passed -Wl,--as-needed. Outside that box, in a "normal" system, SUSE_ASNEEDED=0. This behavior is puzzling to some people every now and then. https://lists.opensuse.org/opensuse-packaging/2017-05/msg00000.html
I think we should always enable --as-needed for the openSUSE "normal" system.
Debian systems also behave such that an incorrect -l order leads to builds stopping.
Yeah, initially we didn't want this because there was much code in the wild that got it wrong. That time has long gone, so I agree. I'll do the change with next binutils update.
But do we really want to deviate from upstream here?

Well, we already deviate in half of Geeko land. The first maxime is therefore to make it behave equal again across SUSE products. Secondarily is to have a look at what other distros do, and evaluate whether to go with the not-upstream-default behavior. Besides Debian, it would appear that Gentoo also has as-needed enabled. as-needed is one of many strategies to drop unnecessary dependencies and to also find programming errors due to effects of link order sensitiviy (missing libs, etc.). I anecdotally remember solaris ld being link-order-sensitive (but not as-needy) too, so that's that.
In other words, it just helps me and others make somewhat better software.
Actually we can propose to make that change upstream as well, then we wouldn't deviate :-)

We are seeing this issue in gdb-7.9.1-12.1 with this detail: priority = Dump_Priority_High, UseCSX = 1986622032, label = "ate Memory Pool", '\000' <repeats 16 times>}, {nFrames = 4, priority = 1701603654, UseCSX = 1937330976, label = "tem", '\000' <repeats 21 times>, "\201:\000\000\004\000\000"}, {nFrames = 1701603654, priority = 1937330976, UseCSX = 913139060, label = "4", '\000' <repeats 19 times>, "(\003\000\000\004\000\000\000File"}, {nFrames = 1937330976, priority = 544040308, UseCSX = 6778700, label = '\000' <repeats 16 times>, "\032\000\000\000\004\000\000\000vnode/fi"}, {nFrames = 1869505900, priority = 1663067492, UseCSX = 1701340001, label = '\000' <repeats 12 times>, "\002\000\000\000\004\000\000\000CG64 cache\000"}, {nFrames = 0, priority = Dump_Priority_None, UseCSX = 0, label = "\000\000\000\000\000\000\000\000\002\000\000\000\004\000\000\000CBFS FNNCache\000\000"}, {nFrames = 0, priority = Dump_Priority_None, UseCSX = 0, label = "\000\000\000\000\242\000\000\000\002\000\000\000SVM Pages\000\000\000\000\000\000\000\000\000\000"}, ../../gdb/value.c:823: internal-error: value_contents_bits_eq: Assertion `offset2 + length <= TYPE_LENGTH (val2->enclosing_type) * TARGET_CHAR_BIT' failed. A problem internal to GDB has been detected, further debugging may prove unreliable. Quit this debugging session? (y or n)
There is an update for gdb to version 11.1 available, please try that. Please attach the coredump if it still reproduces.

bug.short_desc: gdb build often stalls on OBS

long_desc.thetext:
gdb is among the list of packages that often cause a stall in OBS - OBS detects this after a while and cancels the build.
The issue though is that unreliable builds are a pain and must not happen (especially when being a ring package; it is built very often in the stagings and every fail requires the staging managers to interact)
The current fail I have here stops with:
<[ 6299s] Running target unix/-m32/-fPIC/-pie >[ 6299s] Using /usr/share/dejagnu/baseboards/unix.exp as board description file for target. >[ 6299s] Using /usr/share/dejagnu/config/unix.exp as generic interface file for target. >[ 6299s] Using /home/abuild/rpmbuild/BUILD/gdb-7.11.1/gdb/testsuite/config/unix.exp as tool-and-target-specific interface file. >[ 6299s] Running /home/abuild/rpmbuild/BUILD/gdb-7.11.1/gdb/testsuite/gdb.xml/tdesc-arch.exp ... >[ 6299s] /home/abuild/rpmbuild/BUILD/gdb-7.11.1/build-x86_64-suse-linux/gdb/gdb version 7.11.1 -nw -nx -data-directory /home/abuild/rpmbuild/BUILD/gdb-7.11.1/build-x86_64-suse-linux/gdb/testsuite.unix.-m32.-fPIC.-pie/../data-directory >[ 6299s] >[ 6299s] >[ 6299s] === gdb Summary === >[ 6299s] >[ 6299s] # of expected passes 8 >[ 6300s] /home/abuild/rpmbuild/BUILD/gdb-7.11.1/build-x86_64-suse-linux/gdb/gdb version 7.11.1 -nw -nx -data-directory /home/abuild/rpmbuild/BUILD/gdb-7.11.1/build-x86_64-suse-linux/gdb/testsuite.unix.-m32.-fPIC.-pie/../data-directory >[ 6300s] >[35104s] ### WATCHDOG MARKER END ### >[35104s] No buildstatus set, either the base system is broken (kernel/initrd/udev/glibc/bash/perl) >[35104s] or the build host has a kernel or hardware problem... > > >Job seems to be stuck here, killed. (after 28800 seconds of inactivity)
It would be interesting to recover the buildroot given there are detailled logfiles of the testsuite run ...

Yes indeed. I don't see how I can debug this otherwise as it's not reproducable locally (or at least I seem to be unable to).
I've seen this in the past as well, and I suspect some interaction between the qemu virtualization OBS uses and the specific hw features that gdb uses.
If you have some statistics: is there anything in common on all buildhosts where it stops making progress in difference to those where it finishes?

long_desc.thetext:
Memkind library has been updated to version 1.3.0. This version (among other changes) incorporates additional security flags for library compilation and logging mechanism for easier debugging.
https://github.com/memkind/memkind

bug.short_desc: p11-kit-trust.so tries to use mmap with write+exec

long_desc.thetext:
when p11-kit tries to load the p11-kit-trust.so we run into the following code:
``` 1623 mmap(NULL, 4096, PROT_READ|PROT_WRITE|PROT_EXEC, MAP_PRIVATE|MAP_ANONYMOUS, -1, 0) = 0x3834e70b000 ```
This gets killed by the grsec kernel with:
``` 8097.931220] PAX: From 127.0.0.1: execution attempt in: <anonymous mapping>, 3532a352000-3532a354000 3532a352000 [ 8097.931223] PAX: terminating task: /usr/bin/pdnsutil(pdnsutil):23868, uid/euid: 0/0, PC: 000003532a352010, SP: 000003ab64903928 [ 8097.931224] PAX: bytes at PC: 4c 8d 15 f9 ff ff ff ff 25 03 00 00 00 0f 1f 00 68 b1 25 27 [ 8097.931230] PAX: bytes at SP-8: 000000472c954320 0000035328ba3ef2 0000000000000000 0000000000000000 000000472c954320 000000472c954320 000003ab649039d0 000003ab649039e0 000003ab64903bf0 000003ab64903bd8 0000000000000002 ```
moving /usr/share/p11-kit/modules/p11-kit-trust.module away, "solves" the issue, as the module is no longer loaded. During the discussion with the maintainer of the pkcs#11 part in powerdns, he mentioned that in the future systemd will have a DenyWriteExec option to deny WRITE+EXEC pages there as well. so the grsec kernel will not be the only way to trigger this bug.
complete strace is available if needed.
kernel-grsec-guest-kvm-4.7.2-2.1 obs://build.opensuse.org/home:dsterba:grsecurity/openSUSE_Tumbleweed/68ce05d9439e32ada1b1151bf6f9b7e8-kernel-grsec-guest-kvm
the only mmap p11-kit implements itself (p11_mmap_open in common/compat.c) uses PROT_READ so the mmap you see is from dlopen, ie glibc.
I run other daemons on the same host that use dlopen just fine. it is only the 2 packages which use that fail to start. so in doubt this is libtasn or so that does something weird.
which use p11-kit....
I see not reason why I should invest time here to debug issues you get with a custom kernel. Feel free to report upstream.
because we might want to set DenyWriteExec in service files with future systemd versions.
https://github.com/systemd/systemd/issues/3319

this could be caused by bind_ffi_closure
(gdb) bt #0 __mmap (addr=addr@entry=0x0, len=len@entry=4096, prot=prot@entry=7, flags=flags@entry=34, fd=fd@entry=-1, offset=offset@entry=0) at ../sysdeps/unix/sysv/linux/wordsize-64/mmap.c:33 #1 0x00007ffff71a9a0d in dlmmap (length=length@entry=4096, offset=0, fd=-1, flags=34, prot=3, start=0x0) at ../../../libffi/src/closures.c:536 #2 0x00007ffff71aa4f3 in sys_alloc (m=0x7ffff73af220 <_gm_>, nb=56) at ../../../libffi/src/dlmalloc.c:3515 #3 dlmalloc (bytes=48) at ../../../libffi/src/dlmalloc.c:4245 #4 ffi_closure_alloc (size=size@entry=48, code=code@entry=0x60a158) at ../../../libffi/src/closures.c:616 #5 0x00007ffff7bae870 in bind_ffi_closure (wrapper=wrapper@entry=0x60a150, binding_data=binding_data@entry=0x609f10, binding_func=0x7ffff7bacd80 <binding_C_Initialize>, args=args@entry=0x7ffff7dd3cb0 <function_info+48>, bound_func=0x60a158) at p11-kit/virtual.c:2660 #6 0x00007ffff7baeada in init_wrapper_funcs (wrapper=0x60a150) at p11-kit/virtual.c:2701 #7 p11_virtual_wrap (virt=virt@entry=0x609f10, destroyer=<optimized out>) at p11-kit/virtual.c:2755 #8 0x00007ffff7b92cd1 in prepare_module_inlock_reentrant (mod=0x609520, flags=<optimized out>, module=0x6108d0) at p11-kit/modules.c:1861 #9 0x00007ffff7b93c30 in p11_modules_load_inlock_reentrant (flags=0, results=0x7fffffffd750) at p11-kit/modules.c:1919 #10 0x00007ffff7b93d97 in p11_kit_modules_load (reserved=<optimized out>, flags=0) at p11-kit/modules.c:1991 #11 0x00007ffff7b941ba in p11_kit_modules_load_and_initialize (flags=flags@entry=0) at p11-kit/modules.c:2103 #12 0x0000000000401ebe in print_modules () at p11-kit/lists.c:210 #13 p11_kit_list_modules (argc=1, argv=0x7fffffffe328) at p11-kit/lists.c:289 #14 0x00007ffff73d0711 in __libc_start_main (main=0x401bf0 <main>, argc=2, argv=0x7fffffffe328, init=<optimized out>, fini=<optimized out>, rtld_fini=<optimized out>, stack_end=0x7fffffffe318) at ../csu/libc-start.c:289 #15 0x0000000000401c29 in _start () at ../sysdeps/x86_64/start.S:118
gdb --args p11-kit list-modules catch syscall mmap condition 1 $rdx==7

some more findings:
compile libffi-gcc5 with the following patch: https://gist.github.com/darix/35996fe2be10d40680a359316c045256
makes the tools work even with
paxctl -v /usr/bin/p11* /usr/bin/p11-kit: XATTR_PAX : PEMRS
/usr/bin/p11tool: XATTR_PAX : PEMRS
libffi -> gcc
This is a fix that makes it work https://github.com/libffi/libffi/pull/282
osc rdiff {,home:darix:branches:}devel:gcc/gcc5

bug.short_desc: ARMv8.1/2 debuginfo support missing in gdb

long_desc.thetext:
Partner report: "gdb with ARMv8.1 reports no hw watchpoints or hw breakpoint are supported"
The patch which they need to backport for this support is located at:
https://sourceware.org/git/?p=binutils-gdb.git;a=commitdiff_plain;h=49ecef2a7da2ee9df4ae675f99b70518fbf1bb23
scheduled for inclusion in gdb 7.12, but I guess since this is a small thing we could just include it.

Version: binutils-gdb 7.11
Applies to: ARMv8.1/8.2, Cavium ThunderX
Test case:
Start gdb, set breakpoint and run a program.
Build and run a C program with gdb:
$ gcc -g -o main main.c $ gdb main
Set a breapoint and run the program.
bad:
The warning shows that hardware breakpoints are not detected:
(gdb) break main Breakpoint 1 at 0x4005c8: file main.c, line 5. (gdb) run Starting program: /root/test/main warning: Unable to determine the number of hardware watchpoints available. warning: Unable to determine the number of hardware breakpoints available.
Breakpoint 1, main () at main.c:5 5 printf("Hello world.\n");
good:
Breakpoints are detected:
(gdb) break main Breakpoint 1 at 0x4005c8: file main.c, line 5. (gdb) run Starting program: /root/test/main
Breakpoint 1, main () at main.c:5 5 printf("Hello world.\n");
Note: ThunderX 2.0 with newer firmware (since 1.23.6) is not affected.
Looks more like a feature request to me and a kernel / firmware / CPU issue rather than a gdb issue.

(In reply to Richard Biener from comment #2) > Looks more like a feature request to me and a kernel / firmware / CPU issue > rather than a gdb issue.
No, all cpus supporting ARMv8.1 or 8.2 are affected and gdb does not detect and enable those.
There is nothing that kernel or firmware can do here. If you look at the suggested change, it modifies gdb's cpu detection.

(In reply to Robert Richter from comment #3) > (In reply to Richard Biener from comment #2) > > Looks more like a feature request to me and a kernel / firmware / CPU issue > > rather than a gdb issue. > > No, all cpus supporting ARMv8.1 or 8.2 are affected and gdb does not detect > and enable those. > > There is nothing that kernel or firmware can do here. If you look at the > suggested change, it modifies gdb's cpu detection.
Whoops - I missed the link to the patch.

I'll take the patch into our package. There's a maintenance update running for gdb already, hopefully I can include this into that one. If you want to test: the OBS devel:gcc project contains a gdb with this patch. It's still building right now, but once finished a quick smoketest from you Robert would be appreciated.

(In reply to Michael Matz from comment #5) > If you want to test: the OBS devel:gcc project contains a gdb with this > patch. It's still building right now, but once finished a quick smoketest > from you Robert would be appreciated.
Michael, thanks for the build. I have tested 7.11.1-145.1 and it works fine on Cavium ThunderX. Below some logs.
Thanks,
-Robert

bug.short_desc: VUL-0: CVE-2016-5027: libdwarf: Multiple vunerabilities in libdwarf & dwarfdump

long_desc.thetext: Ugh, do we even ship libdwarf anywhere? Certainly not in any SLES or SLED 11. We haven't touched sources of libdwarf since 2008, I bet nothing of the above will apply anymore.
bugbot adjusting priority

On the 11-SP4 SDK we ship libdwarf and libdwarf-devel
libdwarf-devel is used during build for "CodeAnalyst", also on the SDK 11-SP4.
(that said, it is yet again an issue where we need to review if we want to fix it. :/ )
SDK? That's not supported. The way to fix this "vulnerability" is for customers who're concerned about this to deinstall libdwarf (and hence CodeAnalyst).

bug.short_desc: L3-Question: strip command breaks file
bug.product: SUSE Linux Enterprise Server 11 SP2 (SLES 11 SP2)

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 543276 hello.c, stripped and non-striiped files, and the used script
The customer has reported the following:
-- We use a custom installation service that allows to distribute files contained on a CD to any number of machines. These CDs contain an script that transfer files from the CD to the installation server. This installation server used to be a TRU64 machine that distributed the software to Tru64 machines. We are currently in the process of migrating the installation server to SLES. The migrated installation server must distribute the CD content to both Tru64 and Linux machines.
Unfortunately, the script contained on the CDs (read only!) strips all binaries before copying them to a file structure on the installation server. When adding old in-the-wild media, the SLES strip utility breaks ALL Tru64 binaries and renders the installation server unusable for Tru64 machines.
--
In summary the customer does strip an object file from a UNIX system in a 32-bit Linux system and does use it back in the UNIX system. And the error looks like the following (can be seen in the attached tar):
./hello_gnu_stripped: /sbin/loader: Fatal Error: Main's RLD_VERSION is 0, the correct version should be 3
Attached is the hello.c file, the stripped and not stripped object file, and the used script.
NB: The customer reported that it works on RHEL without error message.
Michael, what do you think? What guarantee do we make that strip can operate on non-Linux binaries?

Can they provide us with the output from 'strip --version' on the RHEL system that works for them?
It looks like GNU strip adds a .bss section at the beginning and moves all other sections.
In theory it should work to strip ECOFF little-endian alpha files.
objdump --headers
helps to highlight the differences.

Actually, I'd like to also see the resulting stripped binary when stripping on RHEL. What our strip does in comparison to DEC strip is, it leaves the .comment section in the executable, and places the data blobs from the sections in the file a bit different. The content of all sections is otherwise byte identical to the DEC stripped executable.
So it must be something outside sections that makes the difference, which is fully possible, but for that I'd like to see the RHEL result.
Generally I don't think we really L3-support this usecase, but we should nevertheless fix it if possible.

Please also make the customer try with these arguments to strip: "-R .bss". I.e. "strip -R .bss -o hello_gnu_stripped_try2 hello" .
This leads to the strange additional .bss section (which the original exe doesn't have) to not be emitted, and makes the file offsets as side effect the same as the original exe, in particular the .dynamic section stays directly behind the ecoff headers and section tables (at offset 0x470).
With the added .bss section the .dynamic section moves a page down in the file to offset 0x2470, and if the DEC dynamic loader doesn't look at the section headers to find the .dynamic section but instead simply assumes that it follows right after the section headers (a but of DEC I would say, but hey), then this would explain the error.
Moussa, can you get all the requested information from the customer? We can't make any progress without it.
OK, I will ask again and get back to you.
The customer is on vacation and we will not get an answer from him before 1 or 2 weeks.
Kim, I will be out of office during the next two weeks, please feel free to update this bug when you have an update from the customer.

I have to say that I tried run strip on Centos6.4 and strip doesn't recognize architecture ecoff-littlealpha.
My testcase: [root@dhcp56 tmp1]# cat /etc/redhat-release CentOS release 6.4 (Final)
[root@dhcp56 tmp1]# rpm -qa binutils binutils-2.20.51.0.2-5.36.el6.x86_64
[root@dhcp56 tmp1]# strip hello_strip_tru2 strip:hello_strip_tru2: File format not recognized
[root@dhcp56 tmp1]# strip Usage: strip <option(s)> in-file(s) Removes symbols and sections from files ..... strip: supported targets: elf64-x86-64 elf32-i386 a.out-i386-linux pei-i386 pei-x86-64 elf64-l1om elf64-little elf64-big elf32-little elf32-big srec symbolsrec verilog tekhex binary ihex
CentOS is binary compatible with RHEL.
objdump -Dslx hello |less hello: file format ecoff-littlealpha hello architecture: alpha, flags 0x00000172: EXEC_P, HAS_SYMS, HAS_LOCALS, DYNAMIC, D_PAGED start address 0x0000000120001030
I am really curious what version of RHEL customer tested. :-)

One more note. I think that objcopy --strip-debug works correctly:
objcopy --strip-debug hello test_out
FLAG is still same: test_out: file format ecoff-littlealpha test_out architecture: alpha, flags 0x00000172: EXEC_P, HAS_SYMS, HAS_LOCALS, DYNAMIC, D_PAGED start address 0x0000000120001030
and .bss part was added also:
16 .bss 00000000 0000000000000000 0000000000000000 00000000 2**4 ALLOC
but strip of unneeded is bad:
objcopy --strip-unneeded test_out test
FLAG was changed: test: file format ecoff-littlealpha test architecture: alpha, flags 0x00000142: EXEC_P, DYNAMIC, D_PAGED start address 0x0000000120001030
It seems like bad address rewrite pattern by my opinion.
For example from 11fffab30 to 0x11fffab30:
.... - 120000674: 2e 69 6e 69 jsr s2,(s5),11fffab30 <_fpdata_size+0x11fffab27> + 120000674: 2e 69 6e 69 jsr s2,(s5),0x11fffab30 .....
Michael, what do you think about it?

Created attachment 553499 Requested files
(In reply to comment #4) > Please also make the customer try with these arguments to strip: "-R .bss". > I.e. "strip -R .bss -o hello_gnu_stripped_try2 hello" .
Customer finally came back to us, please see feedback below: >> Success! hello_gnu_stripped_try2 works on Tru64 4.0f. RHEL strip (binutils-2.20.51.0.2-5.36.el6.x86_64) bails out with "strip:hello: File format not recognized" <<
Customer also provided the requested files - I have attached them

It is surprise for me that strip on RHEL works.
I did same test case on SLES and compared both:
strip -R .bss -o hello_gnu_stripped_try2_SLES11SP2 hello
objdump -Dslx hello_gnu_stripped_try2_SLES11SP2 > hello_gnu_stripped_try2_SLES11SP2.txt
....
dhcp79:~/823845/tmp1 # diff -u 2013-08-20/hello_gnu_stripped_try2.txt hello_gnu_stripped_try2_SLES11SP2.txt --- 2013-08-20/hello_gnu_stripped_try2.txt 2013-08-21 15:53:08.000000000 +0200 +++ hello_gnu_stripped_try2_SLES11SP2.txt 2013-08-21 17:46:25.000000000 +0200 @@ -1,6 +1,6 @@
-hello_gnu_stripped_try2: file format ecoff-littlealpha -hello_gnu_stripped_try2 +hello_gnu_stripped_try2_SLES11SP2: file format ecoff-littlealpha +hello_gnu_stripped_try2_SLES11SP2 architecture: alpha, flags 0x00000142: EXEC_P, DYNAMIC, D_PAGED start address 0x0000000120001030
It same output. Files have only different names.

I would like complete differences between RHEL and SUSE.
Can you provide that test case?
strip -o hello_gnu_stripped_try3 hello
Please, attach hello_gnu_stripped_try3 here.

Based on the information the customer provided in the e-mail, the file "hello_gnu_stripped_try2" is the result of the command:
strip -R .bss -o hello_gnu_stripped_try2 hello
on a SLES machine. This file is now working on their Tru64 machine.
The file "hello_osf1_stripped" is supposed to be the file stripped with RHEL but in the customer e-mail he wrote that "RHEL bails out with "strip:hello: File format not recognized" so I would assume it's the "un-stripped" version. (Waiting on customer to confirm this).
Just to be sure :-) - from which machine do you want the test case in Comment #13 ?

I'm back.
Can you test it this on SLES?
objcopy --strip-debug hello test_out
And run on Tru64?
I writed in the Comment 10.
Thanks

(In reply to comment #10) > One more note. I think that objcopy --strip-debug works correctly: > > objcopy --strip-debug hello test_out > > FLAG is still same: > test_out: file format ecoff-littlealpha > test_out > architecture: alpha, flags 0x00000172: > EXEC_P, HAS_SYMS, HAS_LOCALS, DYNAMIC, D_PAGED > start address 0x0000000120001030 > > and .bss part was added also: > > 16 .bss 00000000 0000000000000000 0000000000000000 00000000 2**4 > ALLOC
That's the same as strip without any options produces, and it's the only real difference to what Tru64 strip produces. The additional .bss section (and hence the moved section headers) seem to confuse the Tru64 linkers/loaders. So as long as it's there, it's bound to not work.
> but strip of unneeded is bad: > > objcopy --strip-unneeded test_out test > > FLAG was changed: > test: file format ecoff-littlealpha > test > architecture: alpha, flags 0x00000142: > EXEC_P, DYNAMIC, D_PAGED > start address 0x0000000120001030
Well, that's expected. --strip-unneeded will indeed strips out the .symtab. The flags printed here are BFD flags invented by the ELF reader of libbfd, it's not really part of the ELF file (but based on information in it). To see only the ELF contents use readelf.
> It seems like bad address rewrite pattern by my opinion. > > For example from 11fffab30 to 0x11fffab30: > > .... > - 120000674: 2e 69 6e 69 jsr s2,(s5),11fffab30 > <_fpdata_size+0x11fffab27> > + 120000674: 2e 69 6e 69 jsr s2,(s5),0x11fffab30 > .....
Nope, that's simply a change in how the disassembled instruction is output. It misses the 0x prefix when symbol information is there.
We still need the stripped output as produced on RHEL, because the initial comment claimed that customer was able to strip on RHEL and produce a working executable. Now comment #11 indicates that this was incorrect information. so please clarify that first. If RHEL strip also doesn't work, there's not much we can do if we don't have access to a Tru64 system. It's probably a bug in Tru64's loader exposed by GNU strip.

> We still need the stripped output as produced on RHEL, because the initial > comment claimed that customer was able to strip on RHEL and produce a > working executable. Now comment #11 indicates that this was incorrect > information. so please clarify that first. If RHEL strip also doesn't > work, there's not much we can do if we don't have access to a Tru64 system. > It's probably a bug in Tru64's loader exposed by GNU strip.
Is it possible access to some Tru64's? I would like proof about bug in the Tru64 loader.

I have spoken to the customer, currently it's not possible to get access to the Tru64 system.
He did however confirm that the RHEL actually doesn't do anything to the file - it simply bails out with "with "strip:hello:File format not recognized".
From the customer perspective, using "strip -R .bss" is a work-around - not a fix.
The current expectation of the customer that they can run the strip command WITHOUT any additional parameters to produce a working result OR that we also just simply error out without touching the file.

Well, we certainly won't remove the possibility to handle executables for alpha from binutils, that's what RHEL seems to do, it simply doesn't recognize them.
I'll try poking at binutils to not add the .bss section when not necessary.

(In reply to comment #19) > Well, we certainly won't remove the possibility to handle executables for alpha > from binutils, that's what RHEL seems to do, it simply doesn't recognize them. > > I'll try poking at binutils to not add the .bss section when not necessary.
Thanks Michael. Let me know when you will have fix.
Michael, do you have any progress on fix?
Not yet, it's very low prio for me.

Michael, while I understand this is low priority for you as an individual, it is still L3, so it does have priority for us as a company selling support to our customers. So I would appreciate if you can allocate some time to it before mid-December.

Kim, it should be clear that Michael will not find the time to work on this in a near future. This was clearly "best effort" rather than a valid L3 case (see comment #3.) Thus I would like to close the L3 ticket for this bug. We can leave the bug itself open if Michael wants. OK?

Sorry, lost track of this bug.
I have spoken to the customer they do have a work-around and therefore do not have a problem with the low prio of this bug. I also did said the customer expectation with regards to when a fix will be available (not likely anytime soon).

attachment.desc: hello.c, stripped and non-striiped files, and the used script

bug.short_desc: gcc segfaults compiling Linux 3.7-rc3's gfs2 code
bug.product: SUSE Linux Enterprise Server 10 SP4 (SLES 10 SP4)

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 511726 cut down source
See attachment (cut down from fs/gfs2/rgrp.c).
kernel 3.7 on sle10 sp4? Why that? I assume with the most recent system compiler and -O2?

(In reply to comment #1) > kernel 3.7 on sle10 sp4? Why that?
Because that my devel system, allowing to run all currently supported kernels (i.e. from SLE10 [2.6.16.*] up to the tip of master).
> I assume with the most recent system compiler and -O2?
Sorry, should have stated that: Most recent system compiler, and options don't seem to matter (I used just "gcc -c" to get to that broken down example).

Confirmed.
Program received signal SIGSEGV, Segmentation fault. 0x0000000000984c55 in type_contains_placeholder_p (type=0x0) at /space/rguenther/src/svn/gcc-4_1-branch/gcc/tree.c:2167 2167 if (TYPE_CONTAINS_PLACEHOLDER_INTERNAL (type) > 0) ... #16 0x0000000000984d4b in type_contains_placeholder_p (type=0x7ffff7968b00) at /space/rguenther/src/svn/gcc-4_1-branch/gcc/tree.c:2175 2175 result = type_contains_placeholder_1 (type); (gdb) #17 0x00000000004f1da8 in gimplify_init_ctor_preeval (expr_p=0x7ffff7ec4470, pre_p=0x7fffffffbfe0, post_p=0x7fffffffbfd8, data=0x7fffffffba40) at /space/rguenther/src/svn/gcc-4_1-branch/gcc/gimplify.c:2501 2501 if (type_contains_placeholder_p (TREE_TYPE (*expr_p)))
#1 0x00000000009848cd in type_contains_placeholder_1 (type=0x7ffff7968f20) at /space/rguenther/src/svn/gcc-4_1-branch/gcc/tree.c:2136 2136 return type_contains_placeholder_p (TYPE_DOMAIN (type)); (gdb) l 2131 || CONTAINS_PLACEHOLDER_P (TYPE_MAX_VALUE (type))); 2132 2133 case ARRAY_TYPE: 2134 /* We're already checked the component type (TREE_TYPE), so just check 2135 the index type. */ 2136 return type_contains_placeholder_p (TYPE_DOMAIN (type));
which is NULL.
fixed for GCC 4.2+, not worth trying to identify/pick the patch that fixed it.

(In reply to comment #3) > fixed for GCC 4.2+, not worth trying to identify/pick the patch that fixed it.
Meaning SLE10 is intended to be left broken? I didn't report this against upstream gcc as I know it is fixed with newer versions...

(In reply to comment #4) > (In reply to comment #3) > > fixed for GCC 4.2+, not worth trying to identify/pick the patch that fixed it. > > Meaning SLE10 is intended to be left broken? I didn't report this against > upstream gcc as I know it is fixed with newer versions...
The compiler in SLE10 has multiple known (and more serious) bugs.

bug.short_desc: linker segfault/internal error while linking large library, ppc/ppc64

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 488788 build logs (tar.xz)
Linker fails while trying to link libxul (stripped library has usually ~30MB) for Firefox 10.
On PPC, the error is "collect2: ld terminated with signal 11 [Segmentation fault], core dumped"
On PPC64 "/usr/lib64/gcc/powerpc64-suse-linux/4.1.2/../../../../powerpc64-suse-linux/bin/ld: BFD 2.16.91.0.5 20051219 (SUSE Linux) internal error, aborting at ../../bfd/elf64-ppc.c line 5247 in ppc64_elf_gc_sweep_hook"
Attached are build logs )(although I'm not sure that is going to help much). The project/package in question is home:pcerny:SLE-10-SP3/MozillaFirefox

ppc (binutils-2.16.91.0.5-23.34.33):
Program terminated with signal 11, Segmentation fault. #0 ppc_elf_gc_sweep_hook (abfd=<value optimized out>, info=0x101c2aa8, sec=0x102a0518, relocs=0x102a4750) at ../../bfd/elf32-ppc.c:3814 3814 if (ent->plt.refcount > 0) (gdb) bt #0 ppc_elf_gc_sweep_hook (abfd=<value optimized out>, info=0x101c2aa8, sec=0x102a0518, relocs=0x102a4750) at ../../bfd/elf32-ppc.c:3814 #1 0x0feae198 in elf_gc_sweep (info=<value optimized out>, abfd=<value optimized out>) at ../../bfd/elflink.c:9338 #2 bfd_elf_gc_sections (info=<value optimized out>, abfd=<value optimized out>) at ../../bfd/elflink.c:9595 #3 0x10017080 in lang_gc_sections () at ../../ld/ldlang.c:5398 #4 lang_process () at ../../ld/ldlang.c:5450 #5 0x1001ae94 in main (argc=126, argv=0xfff14274) at ../../ld/ldmain.c:461

ppc (binutils219-2.19-0.4.26):
Program terminated with signal 11, Segmentation fault. #0 ppc_elf_gc_sweep_hook (abfd=<value optimized out>, info=0x100ace50, sec=0x10161d08, relocs=0x101661c8) at ../../bfd/elf32-ppc.c:4289 4289 if (ent->plt.refcount > 0) (gdb) bt #0 ppc_elf_gc_sweep_hook (abfd=<value optimized out>, info=0x100ace50, sec=0x10161d08, relocs=0x101661c8) at ../../bfd/elf32-ppc.c:4289 #1 0x0fded03c in elf_gc_sweep (info=<value optimized out>, abfd=<value optimized out>) at ../../bfd/elflink.c:11331 #2 bfd_elf_gc_sections (info=<value optimized out>, abfd=<value optimized out>) at ../../bfd/elflink.c:11590 #3 0x100181cc in lang_gc_sections () at ../../ld/ldlang.c:5939 #4 lang_process () at ../../ld/ldlang.c:6099 #5 0x1001b924 in main (argc=126, argv=0xff9cb534) at ../../ld/ldmain.c:455
Before diving much deeper into this, can you please try with updated binutils (from SLE11 SP2, or even 12.1, i.e. binutils 2.21 or 2.22)?
binutils-2.22 work fine

bug.short_desc: gdb: info frame internal-error: dwarf2_frame_cache

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 441190 includes supportconfigs (sles10sp3,sles11sp1), test binary and source code
Customer saw this on both: SLES10 SP3 - x86_64 - gdb-6.8.50.20090302-1.5.18 SLES11 SP1 - x86_64 - gdb-7.0-0.4.16
The gdb core (see below) is available at: ftp://ftp.novell.com/incoming/core.gdb.
supportconfig (SLES11 SP1 and SLES10 SP3 and test binary and source code, attached to the Bug is also available at: ftp://ftp.novell.com/incoming/gdb-error.tar.gz
While trying to debug an application. customer saw this:
(gdb) info frame 0x7fffffff8bd8 Stack frame at 0x7fffffff8bd8: rip = 0x0; saved rip 0x507680 called by frame at ../../gdb/valops.c:726: internal-error: value_fetch_lazy: Assertion `frame != NULL' failed. A problem internal to GDB has been detected, further debugging may prove unreliable. Quit this debugging session? (y or n) n
When they reproduced it, they got the below error:
The program: /tmp/segfaults/seg is just a simple code that runs in loop, mallocs until it segfaults.
Customer set the break point in main and wanted to see info on frame 1 (which does not exist, btw). When they got the error, they did not quit the debugger, and then, it asked for the core.
(gdb) run The program being debugged has been started already. Start it from the beginning? (y or n) y Starting program: /tmp/segfaults/seg
Breakpoint 1, main () at seg.c:8 8 pointer = malloc(sizeof(int)); (gdb) bt #0 main () at seg.c:8 (gdb) info frame 1 Stack frame at 0x1: rip = 0x0; saved rip dwarf2-frame.c:603: internal-error: dwarf2_frame_cache: Assertion `fde != NULL' failed. A problem internal to GDB has been detected, further debugging may prove unreliable. Quit this debugging session? (y or n) n
dwarf2-frame.c:603: internal-error: dwarf2_frame_cache: Assertion `fde != NULL' failed. A problem internal to GDB has been detected, further debugging may prove unreliable. Create a core file of GDB? (y or n) y
They get the same when they use the core instead:
------------------ host> gdb seg core GNU gdb 6.3 Copyright 2004 Free Software Foundation, Inc. GDB is free software, covered by the GNU General Public License, and you are welcome to change it and/or distribute copies of it under certain conditions. Type "show copying" to see the conditions. There is absolutely no warranty for GDB. Type "show warranty" for details. This GDB was configured as "x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu"...Using host libthread_db library "/lib64/libthread_db.so.1".
Core was generated by `./seg'. Program terminated with signal 11, Segmentation fault.
warning: current_sos: Can't read pathname for load map: Input/output error
Reading symbols from /lib64/libc.so.6...done. Loaded symbols for /lib64/libc.so.6 Reading symbols from /lib64/ld-linux-x86-64.so.2...done. Loaded symbols for /lib64/ld-linux-x86-64.so.2 #0 0x00000000004005bc in main () at seg.c:11 warning: Source file is more recent than executable. 11 pointer[i] = i; (gdb) break main Breakpoint 1 at 0x400594: file seg.c, line 8. (gdb) run Starting program: /tmp/segfaults/seg Breakpoint 1, main () at seg.c:8 8 pointer = malloc(sizeof(int)); (gdb) bt #0 main () at seg.c:8 (gdb) info frame 1 Stack frame at 0x1: rip = 0x0; saved rip dwarf2-frame.c:603: internal-error: dwarf2_frame_cache: Assertion `fde != NULL' failed. A problem internal to GDB has been detected, further debugging may prove unreliable. Quit this debugging session? (y or n) ---------------------
On SLES11, the error is in dwarf2-frame.c:860 instead :603 but the error is the same:
(gdb) info frame 1 Stack frame at 0x1: rip = 0x0; saved rip dwarf2-frame.c:860: internal-error: dwarf2_frame_cache: Assertion `fde != NULL' failed. A problem internal to GDB has been detected, further debugging may prove unreliable.
The above issue looks pretty much like the issue mentioned here: http://sourceware.org/ml/gdb-patches/2009-01/msg00476.html
However SLES11 SP1 includes the patches mentioned in this thread, although it seems the upstream patches are not fixing the problem completely, see the upstream bug reporting this on gdb 7.2.50 http://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=11896
I wasn't able to reproduce this, neither on SLES10 SP3 nor on SLES11. I used the customer's seg.c/seg binary and on SLES10SP3 I get:
(gdb) bt #0 main () at seg.c:8 (gdb) run The program being debugged has been started already. Start it from the beginning? (y or n) y Starting program: /tmp/seg Failed to read a valid object file image from memory.
Breakpoint 1, main () at seg.c:8 8 pointer = malloc(sizeof(int)); (gdb) bt #0 main () at seg.c:8 (gdb) info frame 1 Stack frame at 0x1: rip = 0x0; saved rip 0x7fffffffd550 called by frame at 0x7fffffffd470 Arglist at 0x7fffffffd458, args: Locals at 0x7fffffffd458, Previous frame's sp is 0x7fffffffd468 Saved registers: rip at 0x7fffffffd460
The customer also mentioned he doesn't understand how I could get 'info frame 1', where there's only frame 0. Frame 1 is out of bounds, as the stack only has one frame and it's labeled 0.

gdb seems to interpret the argument to info frame as a frame number if it falls in the range of valid frame numbers (0 only in your case), otherwise it interprets it as address of the frame as you can see from the output:
(gdb) info frame 1 Stack frame at 0x1: ^^^^^ rip = 0x0; saved rip 0x7fffffffd550 called by frame at 0x7fffffffd470 Arglist at 0x7fffffffd458, args: Locals at 0x7fffffffd458, Previous frame's sp is 0x7fffffffd468 Saved registers: rip at 0x7fffffffd460
maybe not entirely intuitive.

I can't reproduce on SLE10 SP3 with gdb-6.8.50.20090302-1.5.18 . I can't reproduce on SLE11 SP1 with gdb-7.0-0.4.16 .
Both gdbs contain the patches mentioned. The problem of http://sourceware.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=11896 is something different (though the symptom is the same, i.e. assertion in dwarf2_frame_cache), as it requires the symbol-files to be removed from under gdbs feet.
Are you really sure that the customer sees the problem with one of these two gdbs on x86_64, with the testprogram they sent?

I couldn't reproduce it either and asked the customer about SLES11 before. He confirmed: "This was sles11sp1, 2.6.32.29-0.3-default, gdb version: gdb-7.0-0.4.16."
He also send the supportconfig from SLES10 SP3 with gdb-6.8.50.20090302-1.5.18. I don't see any reason why he would use a complete different system with different version of gdb.
However I'll confirm again. I find this a bit bizarre too, because he said he can reproduce the problem every time. I couldn't, so I even changed the kernel to their PTF kernel, tried two different gdb versions to no avail.
I'll get the confirmation by Monday, so if you have any suggestions what I could let them test, please let me know.

Well, there's no hope of fixing a problem we don't even see. The patches supposedly helping with the symptom are already in, so we can't even provide them with a test package checking if certain patches solve the problem.

The customer now is trying to figure out what specific settings might be triggering this. Maybe some environment variables or how the core and the binary are called (./ or directly or full path). I'll let you know if there are any further details and appreciate if you could leave this open for a little longer.
OK, accepted as L3 but we'll see if there is anything to do.

The customer will be on vacation until August 13th and I'll be gone next week until August 23rd. Unfortunately I think it will take at least a month to get some feedback. If you like, you can close the Bug and I'll re-open, if the customer gets back to me with some new evidence.

I agree. The best case would be if the evidence is so clear you can reproduce the problem :-)
closing L3

bug.short_desc: gdb backtraces full of "?"s, rendering them useless

long_desc.thetext:
Report from Cray:
gdb 7.0-0.4.16) has a bug that causes its backtraces to be so full of question marks as to be useless. kaibab> gdb ./testMPIApp core.atp.3922895.1 GNU gdb (GDB) SUSE (7.0-0.4.16) ... Reading symbols from /lus/nid00030/rwm/testMPIApp...done. Core was generated by `./testMPIApp 1 4'. Program terminated with signal 3, Quit. #0 0x00000000004e8fd7 in sched_yield () at ../sysdeps/unix/syscall-template.S:82 82 ../sysdeps/unix/syscall-template.S: No such file or directory. in ../sysdeps/unix/syscall-template.S (gdb) bt #0 0x00000000004e8fd7 in sched_yield () at ../sysdeps/unix/syscall-template.S:82 #1 0x00000000004168af in MPIDI_CH3I_Progress () #2 0x000000000081e2d8 in ?? () #3 0x0000000000477b93 in MPIDI_CH3_iStartMsg () #4 0x0000000000000000 in ?? () Current language: auto The current source language is "auto; currently asm". (gdb) q
a locally installed version of gdb-7.2 renders a different output kaibab> gdb ./testMPIApp core.atp.3922895.1 GNU gdb (GDB) 7.2 ... Reading symbols from /lus/nid00030/rwm/testMPIApp...done. [New Thread 27856] Core was generated by `./testMPIApp 1 4'. Program terminated with signal 3, Quit. #0 0x00000000004e8fd7 in sched_yield () at ../sysdeps/unix/syscall-template.S:82 82 ../sysdeps/unix/syscall-template.S: No such file or directory. in ../sysdeps/unix/syscall-template.S (gdb) bt #0 0x00000000004e8fd7 in sched_yield () at ../sysdeps/unix/syscall-template.S:82 #1 0x00000000004168af in MPIDI_CH3I_Progress () #2 0x000000000041741f in MPIDI_CH3U_VC_WaitForClose () #3 0x0000000000428e04 in MPIDI_PG_Close_VCs () #4 0x00000000004244b4 in MPID_Finalize () #5 0x000000000040c4b4 in PMPI_Finalize () #6 0x00000000004006e0 in main (argc=3, argv=0x7fffffffad18) at ./testMPIApp.c:138
SP1 gdb update to the SP2 version will be available from the GU channel at some point.
Right. I don't know exactly when this will be the case, though. So if the customer wants a PTF before that you'll need to start the L3 process.

are there any issues with running a SLES11sp2 version of gdb on a SLES11sp1 system? SP2 isn't due to be released for a while, and we're not going to be way quick to update to it.
I've got the SP2 beta iso downloaded, and I'll give SP2 gdb rpm a try on one of our systems.

I tried the SP2beta version of gdb (7.2.90.20110525-0.4.4) , and it resolves the backtrace problem.
will this be released for SP1 or do we have to wait for SP2?

(In reply to comment #4) > I tried the SP2beta version of gdb (7.2.90.20110525-0.4.4) , and it resolves > the backtrace problem. > > will this be released for SP1 or do we have to wait for SP2?
It (or an even newer version should we update the package once more for SP2) eventually is supposed to be released in the GU channel which I understand as being then also available for SP1. It probably won't be released before SP2 is ready, though, but that isn't in our (the developers) influence anyway. Sorry, I can't say when exactly it will be available officially for SP1.

We have a local workaround that seems to be working, so we won't request a PTF at this time, and will wait for the official release of an updated rpm for SLES11sp1, or the official release of SLES11sp2.
